title: In the Matter of James M. Williams, III
description: This is an attorney disciplinary opinion in which the Court ordered disbarment.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court
In the Matter of James M.
      Williams, III,Â Â Respondent.

Opinion No. 26441
Submitted January 29, 2008 - Refiled March 10, 2008Â Â  

DISBARRED


	
		
			
				Lesley M.
  Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and Barbara M. Seymour, Assistant Deputy
  Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
				
				Larry C.
  Brandt, of Larry C. Brandt, PA, of Walhalla, for respondent.Â  
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary
  matter, respondent[1] and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for
  Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the
  agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to any sanction in Rule
  7(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  We accept the agreement and disbar respondent
  from the practice of law in this state.[2]Â 
  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.Â   
FACTS
Since
  the late 1980s, respondent represented Client and his wife on a variety of
  legal matters.Â  Presently, Client is an elderly man residing in a retirement
  community.Â  Clientâ€™s wife resided in the same facility until her death in
  November 2002.Â   
Respondent
  drafted durable powers of attorney for Client and his wife.Â  In each of the
  documents, respondent was named attorney-in-fact.Â  The durable powers of
  attorney drafted by respondent contained a provision that respondent, as
  attorney-in-fact, had authority to â€œdeal with Attorney in Attorneyâ€™s individual,
  or any fiduciary capacity in buying and selling assets, and lending and
  borrowing money, and in all other transactions irrespective of the occupancy by
  the same person of dual positions.â€Â   
Respondentâ€™s
  representation of Client and his wife in the preparation and execution of the
  durable powers of attorney and the naming of respondent as attorney-in-fact
  presented a conflict of interest.Â  Respondent did not advise Client and his
  wife of this conflict of interest.Â   
Respondent
  admits misappropriating more than $400,000 from Clientâ€™s personal assets for
  his own use and benefit by executing documents, checks, etc., as Clientâ€™s
  attorney-in-fact.Â  Further, respondent borrowed money from Client without
  obtaining his informed consent to the conflict of interest the transactions
  presented.Â  Respondent failed to reduce the terms of Clientâ€™s loans to
  respondent to writing in the form and with the substance required by the Rules
  of Professional Conduct.Â   
Client
  initiated a civil action against respondent.Â  Respondent settled the suit, in
  part by agreeing to pay restitution.Â   
Respondent
  pled guilty to one count of exploitation of a vulnerable adult.Â  He was
  sentenced to eighteen (18) months under house arrest.Â Â Â   
LAW
Respondent admits that, by his
  misconduct, he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of
  Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.8(a) (lawyer shall not enter
  into business transaction with a client unless terms are fair and disclosed,
  client is given opportunity to seek advice of independent counsel, and client
  consents in writing); Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall hold property of client separate
  from lawyerâ€™s own property); Rule 8.4(b)
    (lawyer shall not commit criminal act that reflects adversely on the lawyerâ€™s
    honesty, trustworthiness, or fitness as a lawyer in other respects); Rule
    8.4(c) (lawyer shall not commit criminal act involving moral turpitude); Rule
    8.4(d) (lawyer shall not engage in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit,
    or misrepresentation); and Rule 8.4(e) (lawyer shall not engage in conduct that
    is prejudicial to the administration of justice).Â Â  Â 
Respondent further admits his
  misconduct is grounds for discipline under Rule 7, RLDE, of Rule 413, SCACR,
  specifically Rule 7(a)(5) ( it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to
  engage in conduct tending to pollute administration of justice, bring courts or
  legal profession into disrepute, or conduct demonstrating an unfitness to
  practice law) and Rule 7(a)(6) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to
  violate the oath of office taken upon admission to practice law in this
  state).Â Â   
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline
  by Consent and disbar respondent.Â  Within fifteen (15) days of the date of this
  opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing
  that he has complied with Rule 30 of Rule 413, SCACR, and shall also surrender
  his Certificate of Admission to the Practice of Law to the Clerk of Court.
 
DISBARRED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES and
  BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] Respondent
  was admitted to practice law in this State in 1978.Â  While he practiced law in
  Clemson, South Carolina, for most of his career, respondent was practicing law
  at 125 Bram Cat Alley in Seneca when he was placed on incapacity inactive
  status on August 8, 2007.  
Â We are aware that there is another
  attorney with a very similar name who has practiced law in Seneca for his
  entire career, James L. Williams.Â  This attorney practices law at 107 North
  Fairplay in Seneca, and he has no involvement in this matter and is a member in
  good standing with the South Carolina Bar.
[2] While the agreement was pending before the
  Court, respondent submitted a letter requesting permission to resign from the
  Bar.Â  The request is denied.Â  Â

title: State v. Roach
description: The Court affirmed Roachâ€™s convictions and vacated the portion of the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion that addresses Roachâ€™s hearsay argument
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Petitioner,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Kenneth Roach, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal From York County
Â John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26446
Heard January 8, 2008 - Filed March 10,
  2008Â Â  
VACATED IN PART; AFFIRMED IN PART


	
		
			
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior
  Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia, and Solicitor
  Thomas E. Pope, of York, for Petitioner.
				Chief Appellate Defender Joseph L. Savitz, III, of South Carolina
  Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Kenneth Roach was convicted of multiple
  drug offenses and sentenced to an aggregate term of thirty years in prison.Â 
  Roach appealed to the Court of Appeals, arguing the trial court erred by admitting
  hearsay testimony in violation of the Confrontation Clause and by improperly
  allowing an in-court identification.Â  The Court of Appeals upheld the trial
  judgeâ€™s ruling on the in-court identification but found that the admission of the
  allegedly hearsay testimony violated the Confrontation Clause.Â  However, the
  Court of Appeals determined the admission of the testimony was harmless error
  and affirmed Roachâ€™s convictions.Â  State v. Roach, 364 S.C. 422, 613
  S.E.2d 791 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  We granted the Stateâ€™s petition to review whether
  the allegedly hearsay testimony was improperly admitted at trial.
At oral
  argument before this Court, Roachâ€™s counsel admitted that the State was correct
  in asserting that the hearsay issue was not properly preserved for appellate
  review.Â  We therefore hold that the hearsay issue should not have been
  addressed by the Court of Appeals.Â  Hendrix v. Eastern Distrib., Inc.,
  320 S.C. 218, 464 S.E.2d 112 (1995) (issue not preserved for review before the
  Court of Appeals should not have been addressed and thus portion of opinion was
  vacated by Supreme Court).Â  Accordingly, we affirm Roachâ€™s convictions in
  result only and vacate the portion of the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion that
  addresses the hearsay issue.
VACATED
  IN PART; AFFIRMED IN PART.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice J. Michelle Childs,
  concur.

title: James v. Kelly Trucking Company
description: In this certified question, the Court answered that a plaintiff in South Carolina is not precluded, as a general matter, from maintaining a cause of action for negligent hiring, training, supervision, or entrustment after an employer stipulates that it is vicariously liable for its employeeâ€™s negligence.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Rose L. James
      and Leroy T. James,  Plaintiffs,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Kelly Trucking
      Company and Alvino C. Hymes, Defendants.
			
		
	


ON CERTIFICATION FROM THE UNITED STATES
  DISTRICT COURT
FOR THE DISTRICT OF SOUTH CAROLINA
Joseph F. Anderson, Jr., United States District JudgeÂ Â Â  
 

Opinion No. 26447
Heard September 18, 2007 - Filed March 10,
  2008
CERTIFIED QUESTIONS ANSWERED


	
		
			
				Dwight
  Christopher Moore, of Moore Law Firm, of Sumter, John S. Nichols,Â  of Bluestein
  & Nichols, of Columbia, and S. Randall Hood, of McGowan Hood Felder &
  Johnson, of Rock Hill, for Plaintiffs.
				Kirby
  D. Shealy III, of Baker Ravenel & Bender, of Columbia, for Defendants.
			
		
	


Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  CHIEF
  JUSTICE TOAL:Â  We accepted two certified questions from the United States
  District Court arising out of the situation in which a plaintiff, as a result
  of allegedly tortious actions by an employee, asserts causes of action for vicarious
  liability and negligent hiring, training, supervision, or entrustment against an
  employer.Â  The first question asks whether a plaintiff in South Carolina is precluded,
  as a general matter, from maintaining a cause of action for negligent hiring,
  training, supervision, or entrustment after an employer stipulates that it is vicariously
  liable for its employeeâ€™s negligence.Â  In the event we answer the first
  question â€œyes,â€ the second question asks whether there is an exception to this
  general rule when the negligent hiring, training, supervision, or entrustment
  claim involves a properly pled and available claim for punitive damages.Â  We
  answer the first question â€œno,â€ and therefore do not reach the second.

Factual/Procedural Background
Rose
  and Leroy James commenced this action to recover for injuries sustained in an
  automobile accident caused by defendant Alvino Hymes.Â  Hymes was driving a
  tractor-trailer truck for his employer, defendant Kelly Trucking Company, when
  he failed to stop for a red light and struck Mrs. Jamesâ€™ vehicle.Â  The James
  sued both Hymes and Kelly Trucking, seeking to hold Kelly Trucking liable for
  Hymesâ€™ negligence through the doctrine of respondeat superior. Â The James also asserted
  a separate cause of action against Kelly Trucking for the negligent hiring,
  training, and supervision of Hymes based on his poor driving record.Â  In their
  prayer for relief, the James sought both actual and punitive damages.
The
  James settled with the insurers of both Hymes and Kelly Trucking, and then
  sought recovery under the underinsured motorists provision (UIM) of their
  insurance policy.Â  The Jamesâ€™ insurer (â€œthe Insurerâ€) then assumed the defense
  of this case as allowed by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-160 (Supp. 2006).Â  The Insurer,
  defending the action from the defendantsâ€™ perspective, stipulated that Hymes
  was negligent in causing the accident and that Hymes was acting in the course
  and scope of his employment with Kelly Trucking when the accident occurred.Â  The
  Insurer then moved for partial summary judgment, arguing that the James were
  precluded from proceeding with their negligent hiring claim because Kelly
  Trucking had admitted liability for Hymesâ€™ negligence.Â   
It
  was against this backdrop that the District Court certified two questions to
  this Court, questions which we accepted pursuant to Rule 228, SCACR.Â  The
  District Court asked:

	
		
			I. 
			Does South Carolina law prohibit 
			a plaintiff from pursuing a negligent hiring, training, supervision, 
			or entrustment claim once respondeat superior liability has been admitted?
 
		
		
			II.
			 If the answer to question 1 
			is in the affirmative, does South Carolina law recognize an 
			exception to the rule where punitive damages on the negligent 
			hiring, training, supervision, or entrustment claim are pled and 
			available?
		
	


Law/Analysis
A plaintiff in a
  civil case may have a number of causes of action at his disposal through which
  he may seek to hold a tortfeasor or other responsible party liable for his
  injury, and this is no less the case when a plaintiff alleges that he has been
  injured by an employee acting in the course and scope of his employment.Â  The
  doctrine of respondeat superior provides that the employer, as the employeeâ€™s
  master, is called to answer for the tortious acts of his servant, the employee,
  when those acts occur in the course and scope of the employeeâ€™s employment.Â  Sams
    v. Arthur, 135 S.C. 123, 128-131, 133 S.E. 205, 207-08 (1926).Â  Such
  liability is not predicated on the negligence of the employer, but upon the
  acts of the employee, whether those acts occurred while the employee was going
  about the employerâ€™s business, and the agency principles that characterize the
  employer-employee relationship.Â  Id.
Just as an employee
  can act to cause anotherâ€™s injury in a tortious manner, so can an employer be
  independently liable in tort.Â  In circumstances where an employer knew or
  should have known that its employment of a specific person created an undue
  risk of harm to the public, a plaintiff may claim that the employer was itself
  negligent in hiring, supervising, or training the employee, or that the employer
  acted negligently in entrusting its employee with a tool that created an
  unreasonable risk of harm to the public.Â  See Restatement (Second) of Torts Â§ 317 (1965) (Cited with
    approval in Degenhart v. Knights of Columbus, 309 S.C. 114, 116, 420 S.E.2d
  495, 496 (1992)).Â  As this recitation suggests, the employerâ€™s liability under
  such a theory does not rest on the negligence of another, but on the employerâ€™s
  own negligence.Â  Stated differently, the employerâ€™s liability under this theory
  is not derivative, it is direct.[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
The Insurer
  argues that pubic policy justifies the preclusion of the pursuit of a negligent
  hiring, training, supervision, or entrustment claim against an employer when the
  employer admits vicarious liability.Â  The argument goes that the admission of evidence
  which must be offered to prove a negligent hiring, training, supervision, or
  entrustment claim - evidence such as a prior driving record, an arrest record,
  or other records of past mishaps or misbehavior by the employee - will be highly
  prejudicial if combined with a stipulation by the employer that it will
  ultimately be vicariously liable for the employeeâ€™s negligent acts.Â  The Insurer
  argues that allowing a plaintiff to maintain an independent negligence cause of
  action against the employer will require that evidence of an employeeâ€™s past
  negligence be admitted.Â  This admission, in the Insurerâ€™s view, will result in
  the jury improperly inferring that because the employee was negligent in the
  past, he was negligent in causing the plaintiffâ€™s injuries.Â  The Insurer argues
  that this inference will lead to a jury verdict driven more by emotion than by
  application of the law. Â Although we do not take these arguments lightly, we
  believe that they do not accurately characterize the concerns at play.Â   
Primarily,
  we think the argument that an independent cause of action against an employer
  must be precluded to protect the jury from considering prejudicial evidence
  presumes too much.Â  Our court system relies on the trial court to determine when
  relevant evidence is inadmissible because its probative value is substantially
  outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, confusion of the issues, or
  misleading the jury.Â  Rule 403, SCRE.Â  Similarly, we rely on the trial
  court to craft instructions describing what a jury may or may not infer from a
  particular piece of evidence, and we grant the trial court discretion to give such
  instructions to the jury at the time such evidence is introduced, when charging
  the jury at the close of the case, or at any proper time in between.Â  In our
  view, the argument that the court must entirely preclude a cause of action to protect
  the jury from considering prejudicial evidence gives impermissibly short-shrift
  to the trial courtâ€™s ability to judge the admission of evidence and to protect
  the integrity of trial, and to the juryâ€™s ability to follow the trial courtâ€™s
  instructions.  
If
  this fact alone did not provide a sufficient basis to reject the proposition at
  issue, the additional complexities involved with adopting such a rule and the
  proposed exception would provide the tiebreaker.Â  To its credit, the Insurer
  stipulates that if a plaintiff should generally be prohibited from pursuing a
  negligent hiring, training, supervision, or entrustment claim once respondeat superior
  liability has been admitted, there should be an exception to this rule where an
  employerâ€™s conduct is so reckless or wanton that punitive damages are available.Â 
  Although this exception appears fairly benign on the surface, we think it
  raises procedural problems of its own.[2]Â  
 
When
  judging whether a plaintiff may proceed to trial on a cause of action, the
  trial court typically concerns itself only with whether the plaintiffâ€™s
  complaint states a factual basis to support a cause of action and whether, at
  the close of his presentation of the case, the plaintiff has presented a prima
  facie case supporting the allegations of his complaint.Â  If the trial court,
  under the exception proposed, is asked to make any sort of a qualitative
  judgment regarding the employerâ€™s conduct, the exception would drastically alter
  our traditional concepts of the courtâ€™s proper function.Â  On the other hand, if
  the trial court is simply required to ask whether the plaintiff has requested
  an award of punitive damages, we think the adoption of a rule of preclusion might
  prove of little utility.Â  As requests for punitive damages are commonplace in
  cases of this type, we think traveling the road the Insurer proposes would
  create an exception which swallows the rule.Â  Â Â 
We
  recognize that other jurisdictions have answered these questions differently, see,
    e.g., McHaffie v. Bunch, 891 S.W.2d 822, 826 (Mo. 1995, but we are not
  resolved to agree in this instance.Â  In our view, it is a rather strange
  proposition that a stipulation as to one cause of action could somehow
  â€œprohibitâ€ completely the pursuit of another.Â  A plaintiff may, in a single
  lawsuit, assert many causes of action against a defendant.Â  The considerations
  limiting a plaintiffâ€™s available causes of action in the typical case are that
  the plaintiff must be able to demonstrate a prime facie case for each cause of
  action and that a plaintiff may ultimately recover only once for an injury.Â  Thus,
  although the Insurerâ€™s stipulation as to vicarious liability ensures that the Insurer
  (standing in the shoes of Kelly Trucking) will be liable for the Jamesâ€™ injuries,
  that is only the practical effect of the stipulation.Â  Such practical
  considerations, in our opinion, ought not require the preclusion of a claim
  based upon Kelly Truckingâ€™s alleged negligence in hiring Hymes as a matter of
  law.

Conclusion
After
  considering the arguments in favor of answering the first certified question in
  the affirmative, we are of the opinion that the largely policy-based arguments
  offered in support of such an answer do not justify a grant of approval to the
  rule proposed.Â  Accordingly, we conclude that South Carolina law does not
  prohibit a plaintiff from pursuing a negligent hiring, training, supervision,
  or entrustment claim once respondeat superior liability has been admitted, and
  we therefore answer the first certified question â€œno.â€Â  For this reason, we
  need not reach the second question certified by the District Court.  
PLEICONES and
  BEATTY, JJ., concur. MOORE, J. dissenting in a separate opinion in which
  WALLER, J. concurs. 
JUSTICE
  MOORE:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  I
  would hold that a plaintiff may proceed on a negligent hiring claim when the
  employer admits vicarious liability only if there is evidence of gross
  negligence in hiring that would support an award of punitive damages.
As a
  general rule, most jurisdictions do not allow a separate claim against an
  employer where vicarious liability is admitted for the acts of an employee.Â  See McHaffie v. Bunch, 891 S.W.2d 822, 826 (Mo. 1995), and cases cited
    therein; Annot. 30 A.L.R. 4th 838 (1984).[3]Â 
  The rationale is that the employerâ€™s liability is a derivative claim fixed by a
  determination of the employeeâ€™s negligence.Â  Some courts following this general
  rule, however, will allow a negligent hiring claim to proceed when the
  employerâ€™s liability is alleged to include gross negligence in hiring;
  in this situation, the employerâ€™s gross negligence supports a claim beyond the
  employeeâ€™s negligent act.Â  See Durben v. American Materials, Inc.,
  503 S.E.2d 618 (Ga. 1998);Â  Lockett v. Bi-State Transit Auth., 445
  N.E.2d 310 (Ill. 1983); Coville v. Ryder Truck Rental, Inc., 795
  N.Y.S.2d 708 (2006); see also Bruck v. Jim Walter Corp., 470
  So.2d 1141 (Ala. 1985).Â  Finally, a minority of courts will allow a negligent
  hiring claim to proceed, irrespective of gross negligence on the employerâ€™s
  part, because they hold that negligent hiring is a separate, and not
  derivative, claim.Â  See Quinonex v. Andersen, 696 P.2d 1342 (Ariz. 1984); Marquis v. State Farm Fire and Cas. Co., 961 P.2d 1213 (Kan. 1998); Lim v. Interstate System Steel Div., Inc., 435 N.W.2d 830 (Minn. 1989).Â  The majority has chosen to follow the minority rule.
Contrary to the
  minority view, our precedent indicates that generally a claim against an
  employer under a theory of respondeat superior is treated as a derivative claim
  dependent upon establishing the negligence of the employee.Â  For instance, in David
    v. McLeod Reg. Med. Center, 367 S.C. 242, 250, 626 S.E.2d 1, 5 (2006), a
  plaintiff alleged medical malpractice by the treating physicians and vicarious
  liability of the hospital.Â  We held summary judgment was properly granted in
  favor of the hospital because the plaintiff had failed to establish negligence
  by the physician-employees.Â  Similarly, in McCullem v. Liberty Life Ins. Co.,
  217 S.C. 565, 571, 61 S.E.2d 181, 184 (1950), we upheld a nonsuit in the
  plaintiffâ€™s action against an employer for injuries allegedly caused by an
  employee where there was no evidence of the employeeâ€™s negligence.Â  Both these
  cases indicate that generally an employerâ€™s liability is determined by the
  negligence of his employee and the suit against the employer is a derivative
  one.[4]Â   
In
  some circumstances, a plaintiff may allege the employerâ€™s negligence rises to
  such a level that it supports liability in addition to the employerâ€™s
  vicarious liability for the employeeâ€™s negligent acts.[5]Â 
  I would allow a separate cause of action in this circumstance because the cause
  of action against the employer is no longer simply derivative of, or dependent
  upon, the negligence of the employee.[6]Â 
  Allowing such an action against an employer would further the deterrent purpose
  of punitive damages.Â  See Clark v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Pub.
    Safety, 362 S.C. 377, 608 S.E.2d 573 (2005) (upholding verdict on claim of
  negligent supervision where there was evidence of employerâ€™s gross negligence
  despite juryâ€™s failure to find employeeâ€™s breach of a duty); Clark v.
    Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 378, 529 S.E.2d 528, 533 (2000) (purposes of
  punitive damages are to punish wrongdoer and deter similar reckless, willful,
  wanton, or malicious conduct in the future).[7]Â 
  I depart from the majorityâ€™s holding because I would not allow a separate cause
  of action to proceed where there is no evidence of gross negligence on the
  employerâ€™s part.Â   
WALLER,
  J., concurs.

[1] Some jurisdictions have limited the application of the theories of negligent
  hiring, training, supervision, and entrustment to instances where an employee
  acts outside the scope of his employment, and this proposition finds some
  support in the comments to the Restatement.Â  See Di Cosala v. Kay, 450
  A.2d 508, 515 (N.J. 1982); and Restatement
  (Second) Â§ 317 cmt. a.Â  Our case law has not previously recognized such
  a distinction, and the parties in this case did not argue that we should begin
  to do so.Â Â Â   
[2] The Insurer focuses much of its argument on the question of whether an award of
  punitive damages against it, standing in the shoes of the defendants, would be
  constitutional.Â  Though an intriguing question, this was not a question we
  agreed to answer.
[3]Judge
  Anderson, who certified the questions here, applied this majority rule in
  another South Carolina case but acknowledged that this Court has never ruled on
  the issue.Â  Bowman v. Norfolk So. Rwy., 832 F.Supp. 1014, 1021-22
  (D.S.C. 1993).  
[4]Similarly,
  in Longshore v. Saber Security Servs., Inc., 365 S.C. 554, 619 S.E.2d 5
  (Ct. App. 2005), the Court of Appeals speculated that a plaintiff must prove an
  actionable tort by the employee in order to maintain a negligent hiring action
  against the employer.Â   
[5]Defendants do not argue against adopting such a rule.Â 
  Instead, they simply claim that any punitive damages award in this case is
  unconstitutional.Â  This is not a question we agreed to answer in accepting the
  questions certified by the District Court.
[6]For
  instance, here plaintiffs claim Hymesâ€™ poor driving record supports punitive
  damages against Kelly Trucking irrespective of any showing that Hymes himself
  was grossly negligent.Â   
[7]I
  note that by giving a limiting instruction, the trial court may restrict the
  use of evidence regarding the negligent hiring claim to avoid the potential danger
  of unfair prejudice from the juryâ€™s consideration of such evidence in the
  context of the underlying tort.Â  For instance, here the jury could be
  instructed that Hymesâ€™ poor driving record is not to be considered in
  determining liability for the wreck but is admissible only on the negligent
  hiring claim.Â  See Lockett, supra.Â

title: Hazel v. State
description: This case involves the issues of whether the Court of Common Pleas erred by finding that respondent's 1979 kidnapping conviction did not involve a sexual offense such that he would be required to register as a sex offender and whether the Court of Common Pleas lacked subject matter jurisdiction to make that finding.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				James Kizer
      Hazel, Jr., Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				State of South Carolina, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Roger L. Couch , Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26448
Heard January 9, 2008 - Filed March 10,
  2008Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy
  Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Deputy Attorney General T. Stephen Lynch, Assistant
  Attorney General David A. Spencer, of Columbia, for appellant.
				Charles Preston Edwards, of Spartanburg, for
  respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  MOORE:Â  After respondentâ€™s request for a declaratory judgment was granted,
  the State appealed.Â  We certified the appeal from the Court of Appeals.
FACTS
Respondent
  pled guilty to kidnapping in 1979 and was sentenced to life imprisonment.[1]Â 
  He served twenty-two years of his sentence and was granted parole in 2002.Â 
  Upon release, he was informed that he would be required to register on the Sex
  Offender Registry.Â  Respondent has registered annually since that time.[2]
Respondent was
  required to register pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-3-430 (2007), which
  provides that persons convicted of certain offenses
  must register as sex offenders upon their release.Â  The current Â§ 23-3-430(C)(15) (2007) requires that any person convicted
  of kidnapping a person eighteen years of age or older must register as a sex
  offender unless a finding is made on the record that the kidnapping did not
  include a criminal sexual offense or attempted criminal sexual offense.
Respondent filed a
  petition for declaratory judgment requesting that he not be required to
  register as a sex offender.Â  The petition was originally regarded as a PCR
  application; however, it was subsequently removed from the PCR docket and
  placed on the Common Pleas non-jury docket.Â  Respondentâ€™s and the Stateâ€™s
  motions for summary judgment were denied.
A bench trial was
  held and an order was issued finding that the transcript of the plea made it
  clear there was no sexual element involved in the kidnapping.Â  The court found the
  trial judge did not make a specific finding that sex was not involved in the
  kidnapping because the law that required him to do so was not yet in effect.Â 
  The court further found that the legislative intent behind the 1998 amendment
  to Â§ 23-3-430 was to protect the public from sexual offenders who may re-offend
  and the court found this was certainly not the case with respondent.Â  The court
  granted respondentâ€™s motion for declaratory judgment and found that respondent
  is not required to register as a sex offender.
ISSUES

	
		
			I.   
			Did the Court of Common Pleas err 
			by finding that respondentâ€™s 1979 kidnapping conviction did not 
			involve a sexual offense such that he would be required to register 
			as a sex offender?
 
		
		
			II.   
			Did the Court of Common Pleas 
			lack subject matter jurisdiction to make a factual finding that 
			respondentâ€™s kidnapping conviction did not involve a sexual offense?
		
	

DISCUSSION
I
The
  State argues respondent became a sex offender upon the enactment of the 1994
  amendment to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-3-430, and that the court erred by applying
  the 1998 amendment to him.
Section 23-3-430
  has been through many changes since its enactment in 1994.Â  In the beginning,
  the statute provided that a person convicted of kidnapping shall be referred to
  as a sex offender.Â  Â§ 23-3-430(8) (Supp. 1995).Â  The statute was amended in
  1996 and kidnapping was deleted from the listing of offenses that require one
  to register as a sex offender.Â  Â§ 23-3-430(C) (Supp. 1996).Â  In 1998, the
  statute was again amended and kidnapping was re-added as one of the enumerated
  offenses.Â  An exception was added to state that if the court makes a finding on
  the record that the offense did not include a criminal sexual offense, then a
  defendant convicted of kidnapping would not be required to register as a sex
  offender.Â  Â§ 23-3-430(C)(15) (Supp. 1998).
The statute was
  again amended in 1999.Â  This amendment rewrote the kidnapping subsection to
  state that a person convicted of kidnapping a person eighteen years of age or
  older would be required to register as a sex offender.Â  The exception was again
  included and stated that no registration would be required if the court made a
  finding on the record that the offense did not include a criminal sexual
  offense or an attempted criminal sexual offense.Â  Â§ 23-3-430(C)(15) (Supp.
  1999).[3]
The 1994 version of
  the statute does not apply to respondent.Â  We conclude the applicable statute
  is the statute that existed at the time of respondentâ€™s release from prison.[4]Â 
  Section 23-3-430 had no effect on respondent until he was released from prison
  and was required to register as a sex offender.Â  Applying the law as it read on
  the date of respondentâ€™s release best fulfills the legislatureâ€™s intent because
  respondent is not at risk of re-offending where his crime did not have involve
  a sexual element.Â  South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 23-3-400 (2007) states:

	The intent of this article is to promote the stateâ€™s fundamental
  right to provide for the public health, welfare, and safety of its citizens. .
  . .
	The sex
  offender registry will provide law enforcement with the tools needed in investigating criminal offenses.Â 
  Statistics show that sex offenders often pose a high risk of re-offending.Â 
  Additionally, law enforcementâ€™s efforts to protect communities, conduct
  investigations, and apprehend offenders who commit sex offenses are impaired by
  the lack of information about these convicted offenders who
  live within the law enforcement agencyâ€™s jurisdiction.

See also State v. Walls, 348 S.C. 26, 558 S.E.2d 524
  (2002) (the language of Â§ 23-3-400 makes clear that the legislature did not
  intend to punish sex offenders, but instead intended to protect the public from
  those sex offenders who may re-offend and to aid law enforcement in solving sex
  crimes).
Accordingly, the
  1999 version of Â§ 23-3-430(C)(15) applies to respondent because he was released
  and required to register in 2002.[5]Â 
  The 1999 amendment states that a person convicted of kidnapping a person
  eighteen years of age or older would be required to register as a sex offender,
  with the exception that no registration would be required if the court made a
  finding on the record that the offense did not include a criminal sexual
  offense or an attempted criminal sexual offense.Â  In the instant case, no such
  finding was made on the record because the amendment did not exist at that
  time.Â  The record is clear, however, that no sexual misconduct was involved in
  this kidnapping.Â  Accordingly, the Court of Common Pleas properly found that
  respondent should not be required to register as a sex offender.
II
The
  State argues that the Court of Common Pleas did not have jurisdiction to make a
  factual finding regarding respondentâ€™s kidnapping offense and, instead, such a
  finding could be made only by the General Sessions court.
The Court of Common
  Pleas had the power to make this finding pursuant to the Declaratory Judgment
  Act.Â  See S.C. Code Ann Â§ 15-53-20 (2005) (courts of record within their
  respective jurisdictions shall have power to declare rights, status, and other
  legal relations whether or not further relief is or could be claimed).Â  The
  judge, in the Court of Common Pleas, properly determined respondentâ€™s status as
  affected by Â§ 23-3-430, a civil statute.Â  See State v. Walls, supra (Sex Offender Registry Act not so punitive in purpose or effect as to
  constitute a criminal penalty).Â  As a result, we approve the procedure utilized
  by the Court of Common Pleas and find that court has the power to make the
  determination that a prior kidnapping offense did not involve sexual misconduct
  such that the one convicted is required to register as a sex offender.Â  Accordingly,
  the decision of the lower court is
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur. 
[1]Respondent,
  his former wife, and another man kidnapped a woman and demanded $20,000 from
  her husband.Â  No sexual misconduct was involved in the kidnapping.  
[2]However,
  after the lower courtâ€™s ruling, respondent was removed from the Sex Offender
  Registry.
[3]Three subsequent amendments did not affect this
  subsection.Â  Â§ 23-3-430(C)(15) (2007).  
[4]Further, the kidnapping subsection of the 1994 statute
  was implicitly repealed by the 1996 amendment that removed kidnapping as one of
  the enumerated offenses requiring one to register as a sex offender.Â  See Taylor v. Murphy, 293 S.C. 316, 360 S.E.2d 314 (1987) (repeal of a
  statute operates retrospectively and has the effect of blotting the statute out
  completely as if it had never existed).
[5]The
  lower court incorrectly applied the 1998 amendment; however, using the 1998
  amendment, instead of the 1999 amendment, does not affect the result in this
  case.

title: James v. State
description: This is a reversal of a grant of post-conviction relief.  The PCR court held that Respondent never entered a guilty plea, and the Court found that holding was not supported by the record.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Jonathan James, Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				State of South Carolina, Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal from Orangeburg County
Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 26449
Submitted January 23, 2008 - Filed March
  10, 2008Â Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, and
  Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, of Columbia, for
  Petitioner.
				EvertÂ 
  Comer, Jr., of Denmark, for Respondent.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  This
  is an appeal from a grant of post-conviction relief (â€œPCRâ€) to Respondent
  Jonathan James.Â  Respondent appeared in court for a plea hearing, and at the
  conclusion of the hearing, the plea court sentenced Respondent to seventeen
  years imprisonment.Â  On collateral review, the PCR court found that Respondent
  never entered a plea of guilty and granted relief.Â  This Court granted the Stateâ€™s
  request for a writ of certiorari.Â  Because the record unequivocally reflects
  that Respondent entered a guilty plea, we reverse.

Factual/Procedural Background
The State charged Respondent with several crimes as a
  result of a rather violent domestic disturbance involving Respondent and his
  estranged wife.[1]Â 
  Respondent appeared in court for a plea hearing roughly one week prior to the
  scheduled beginning of his trial, and immediately prior to the plea hearing,
  Respondent executed a â€œplea sheetâ€ - a document which described several rights
  associated with a criminal trial and which required Respondent to list the
  offenses to which he desired to plead guilty as well as the maximum penalties
  for the charges.Â  Respondent submitted this sheet to the plea court during the
  hearing, and at the conclusion of the hearing, the court sentenced Respondent
  to seventeen years imprisonment.Â  Respondent appealed, and the court of appeals
  affirmed Respondentâ€™s convictions and sentence after performing a review of the
  case pursuant to the decision Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967).
Respondent filed an
  application for PCR, contending that he did not voluntarily, knowingly, and
  intelligently enter a guilty plea.Â  After a hearing, the PCR court granted
  relief.Â  The PCR court held, â€œ[u]pon examination of the entire record, it is
  apparent that [Respondent] never entered a guilty plea.Â  He was never asked how
  he pled and never made any statement that could be construed as an admission of
  guilt.â€Â  This Court granted the Stateâ€™s request for a writ of certiorari to
  review the PCR courtâ€™s decision, and the State presents the following issue for
  review:
Did the
  PCR court err in finding that Respondent never entered a guilty plea?

Standard of Review
This Court gives
  great deference to the PCR courtâ€™s findings and conclusions.Â  Caprood v.
    State, 338 S.C. 103, 109, 525 S.E.2d 514, 517 (2000) (citing McCray
      v. State, 317 S.C. 557, 455 S.E.2d 686 (1995)).Â  A PCR courtâ€™s findings
  will be upheld on review if there is any evidence of probative value supporting
  them.Â  Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 119, 386 S.E.2d 624, 626 (1989).Â 
  In the context of a challenge to a guilty plea, a PCR applicant must establish
  both that his plea counselâ€™s representation was deficient and that there is a
  reasonable probability that but for counselâ€™s deficient representation, the
  applicant would not have pled guilty.Â  Smith v. State, 369 S.C. 135,
  137, 631 S.E.2d 260, 261 (2006) (citing Hill v. Lockhart, 474 U.S. 52, 56-58 (1985)).

Law/Analysis
The
  State argues that the PCR court erred in finding that Respondent never entered
  a guilty plea.Â  We agree.
There
  are two fatal flaws in the PCR courtâ€™s order.Â  The first relates to the courtâ€™s
  conclusion that Respondent never made any statement that could be construed as
  an admission of guilt.Â  As a primary matter, it is well-settled that a
  defendant need not admit guilt in order to enter a valid guilty plea.Â  North Carolina v. Alford, 400 U.S. 25, 31 (1970).Â  Instead, a guilty plea
  need only represent a voluntary and intelligent choice among alternative
  courses of action open to the defendant.Â  Id.Â  For this reason, the
  implication that an admission of guilt is a necessary prerequisite to a guilty
  plea does not accurately characterize the law.
But
  this point is not determinative, because even if a guilty plea required an
  admission of guilt, Respondent admitted his guilt at the plea hearing.Â  The
  solicitor at the hearing recounted the factual basis for the charges at length,
  and when the court asked Respondent if he had anything to offer, he responded,
  â€œThis time it just got out of control that night, and I wasnâ€™t going to kill
  her, I know I wasnâ€™t going to - it just got out of control, it got out of
  hand[,] and Iâ€™m sorry.â€Â  In light of this statement, the PCR courtâ€™s conclusion
  that Respondent did not admit his guilt at the plea hearing is directly
  contrary to the evidence in the record.
The
  second flaw in the PCR courtâ€™s order is in its attachment of unnecessary
  significance to the fact that the plea court never specifically asked
  Respondent â€œhow do you plea?â€Â  The argument goes that the plea courtâ€™s failure
  to ask this question is tantamount to a failure by Respondent to enter a plea.Â 
  In our opinion, however, this failure is not fatal to the pleaâ€™s validity.
Respondent
  incorrectly focuses only on the fact that the plea court did not specifically
  ask for his plea.Â  The transcript of the plea hearing cannot be viewed in
  isolation, but must be considered in the full context of the record.Â  Harres
    v. Leeke, 282 S.C. 131, 133, 318 S.E.2d 360, 361 (1984); State v.
      Lambert, 266 S.C. 574, 579, 225 S.E.2d 340, 342 (1976).Â  This
  context requires that we consider both the transcript and Respondentâ€™s conduct
  relating to the execution of the written plea sheet.Â   
The
  plea sheet is instructive because it contains a written manifestation of
  Respondentâ€™s desire to plead guilty and was executed by Respondent immediately
  prior to the plea hearing.Â  Respondent submitted the sheet to the court during
  the plea hearing, and the court examined Respondent regarding the information
  provided in the plea sheet during the hearing.Â  Respondent indicated to the
  plea court that his attorney reviewed the plea sheet with him and that his answers
  were true and correct.Â  This indication, that the answers provided in the plea
  sheet were correct, is the most instructive.Â  This presumably applies to
  Respondentâ€™s affirmative response to the final question on the sheet which
  reads â€œAre you pleading guilty freely and voluntarily?â€Â  The plea sheet and Respondentâ€™s
  conduct at the plea hearing thus unequivocally expressed his desire to plead
  guilty.[2]
Accordingly,
  we hold that the PCR court erred in determining that Respondent did not enter a
  guilty plea.

Conclusion
For
  the foregoing reasons, we reverse the PCR courtâ€™s grant of relief.
MOORE,
  WALLER and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., concurring in result only.

[1] Specifically, the State charged Respondent with assault and battery with intent
  to kill, first degree criminal sexual conduct, and first-degree burglary.Â  
 
[2] Similarly, the plea courtâ€™s imposition of a sentence clearly evidences that the
  court accepted Respondentâ€™s plea.Â  Cf. Gaines v. State, 335 S.C. 376,
  381, 517 S.E.2d 439, 441-42 (1999) (providing that â€œ[t]he clear implication is
  that the trial judge found the pleas voluntary[,] otherwise he would not have
  entered [the] sentences.â€).
(footnote
  continues)
Interestingly, the record in the instant
  case also contains three â€œsentencing sheetsâ€ - documents executed by both
  Respondent and the plea court containing the caption of Respondentâ€™s case, a
  criminal charge, an indication that Respondent has pled guilty to the listed
  charge, and a sentence for the listed charge.Â  This evidence further undercuts
  the proposition that Respondent never pled guilty.

title: Duvall v. South Carolina Budget and Control Board
description: This is a direct appeal where the Court affirms the calculation of appellant's retirement benefits.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Howard E. 
      Duvall, Jr., Appellant,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				South Carolina Budget and Control Board, South Carolina 
      Retirement System, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â L. Casey Manning, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26451
Heard January 22, 2008 - Filed March 10,
  2008Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Danny
  C. Crowe and R. Hawthorne Barrett, both of Turner, Padget, Graham & Laney, of
  Columbia, for Appellant
				Kelly
  Hunter Rainsford, of South Carolina Retirement System, of Columbia, and W.
  Allen Nickles, III, of Gergel, Nickles & Solomon, of Columbia, for
  Respondents.
			
		
	


JUSTICE WALLER: Appellant, Howard E. Duvall, Jr., challenged the
  calculation of his retirement benefits by respondent, the South Carolina
  Retirement System (â€œSCRSâ€).Â  The Administrative Law Court (â€œALCâ€) upheld the
  calculation made by the SCRS, and the circuit court affirmed the ALCâ€™s
  decision.Â  Duvall now directly appeals to this Court.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Duvall has been the executive director of the Municipal
  Association of South Carolina (â€œMASCâ€) since 1992 and has been employed there
  since 1987.Â  Although Duvall is not a state employee, he is an active member in
  the SCRS because the MASC is a participating employer with the SCRS.[1]
Before
  2003, the MASC permitted its employees to accrue unlimited amounts of unused
  annual leave.Â  In October 2002, the MASCâ€™s board of directors changed this
  policy and decided to cap unused leave at 45 days (360 hours).Â  Of the MASCâ€™s
  35-member staff, only four people had unused leave in excess of 45 days, and
  Duvall was one of those four.Â  The MASC board decided that all employees who
  had accumulated leave in excess of 360 hours as of December 31, 2002, would be
  allowed to either use the leave, or be paid the excess annual leave â€œas an
  addition to salaryâ€ prior to leaving the employment of the MASC.Â   
Duvall
  opted to be paid for his excess leave.Â  In the first quarter of 2003, he
  received approximately $18,000 for unused excess annual leave; in the second
  quarter of 2003, he was paid approximately $39,000.Â  The payouts for Duvallâ€™s
  excess leave of 734.8 hours came to a total of $57,997.76.[2]
Duvall decided to retire under the Teacher
  and Employee Retention Incentive (TERI) plan, with an effective retirement date
  of October 1, 2003.[3]Â 
  At the time of his TERI retirement, Duvallâ€™s regular annual salary was
  approximately $147,000.Â  Furthermore, because he still had 45 days of unused
  annual leave at retirement, he received a lump sum payment of $27,637.20 at
  retirement.Â  When the SCRS calculated Duvallâ€™s average final compensation, this
  latter amount was included in the calculation; however, the payments he
  received earlier in 2003 for excess unused annual leave (amounting to over
  $57,000) were excluded from the calculation of his retirement benefits.Â 
 
The estimates done by the
  SCRS projected that if all payments were considered, Duvall would have a
  monthly retirement benefit of $9,224.13; with the excess leave payments excluded,
  the monthly benefit would be $8,053.99.Â  Thus, if the excess leave payments are
  considered this would amount to over $14,000 more in benefits per year.[4]Â   
Duvall challenged the calculation, arguing
  that the $57,997.76 in
  unused annual leave was intended by the MASC to be part of his salary, and
  therefore, he was entitled to have it included for purposes of calculating his
  average final compensation.Â  The SCRS issued a Final Agency Determination which
  found that the system was prohibited by statute from including any payments for
  unused annual leave above the 45-day limit.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  9-1-10(4).
Duvall filed for review with the ALC.Â  After
  a hearing, the ALC upheld the agencyâ€™s decision.Â  Duvall then appealed to the
  circuit court.Â  In addition to arguing that the ALC should be reversed on the
  merits, Duvall also argued that because of a subsequent statutory amendment,
  the case should be remanded back to the ALC.Â  The circuit court affirmed the
  ALCâ€™s ruling.Â  Specifically, the circuit court found that leave payments which
  either exceed 45 days or are made at any time other than â€œat retirementâ€ should
  not be included in the average final compensation calculation.  

ISSUE

	Did the circuit court err in
  affirming the exclusion of excess unused leave payments from the calculation of
  Duvallâ€™s retirement benefits?Â  


DISCUSSION
Duvall argues the circuit
  court erred by finding that SCRS properly excluded the excess annual leave
  payments he received in the first two quarters of 2003 from its calculation of
  his retirement benefits.Â  We disagree.
This
  Court has stated that the retirement statutes â€œshould be liberally construed in
  favor of those to be benefitted and the objective sought to be accomplished.â€ Â King
    v. South Carolina Ret. Sys., 319 S.C. 373, 461 S.E.2d 822 (1995).Â 
  Nevertheless, the SCRS is also â€œadministered under an elaborate statutory and
  constitutional scheme designed to protect the independence, integrity and
  actuarial soundness of the funds.â€Â  Wehle v. South Carolina Ret. Sys.,
  363 S.C. 394, 399, 611 S.E.2d 240, 242 (2005).Â   
â€œAverage final compensationâ€
  is currently defined by statute as:

	[T]he
  average annual earnable compensation[5] of a member during the twelve consecutive quarters of his creditable service on
  which regular contributions as a member were made to the system producing the
  highest such average; a quarter means a period January through March, April
  through June, July through September, or October through December.Â  An
    amount up to and including forty-five daysâ€™ termination pay for unused annual
    leave at retirement may be added to the average final compensation.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 9-1-10(4)
  (Supp. 2007) (emphasis added).
The
  primary rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and effectuate the
  intent of the Legislature.Â  E.g., Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79,
  85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000).Â  When construing statutory language, the
  statute must be read as a whole, and sections which are part of the same
  general statutory law must be construed together and each one given effect.Â  TNS
    Mills, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 331 S.C. 611, 620, 503
  S.E.2d 471, 476 (1998).Â  Moreover, â€œ[a] statute should not be construed by
  concentrating on an isolated phrase.â€Â  South Carolina State Ports Auth. v. Jasper County, 368 S.C. 388, 398, 629 S.E.2d 624, 629 (2006).Â  The Court must
  presume the Legislature intended its statutes to accomplish something and did
  not intend a futile act.Â  TNS Mills, supra.
Citing
  the liberal construction rule of King, supra, Duvall contends
  that because the average final compensation definition only speaks to â€œtermination
  pay for unused annual leave at retirement,â€ those payments made prior to retirement should be included as salary.[6]Â 
  Specifically, Duvall maintains that the Legislature included the phrases â€œtermination
  payâ€ and â€œat retirementâ€ because it intended to refer only to unused leave
  payments made at the actual end of a system memberâ€™s employment.Â  According to
  Duvall, any other interpretation of the statute would ignore those words and
  therefore render the Legislatureâ€™s action as futile.Â   
In
  addition, Duvall asserts that because he is not a state employee, he is not
  restricted to 45 days of annual leave upon retirement; state employees, on the
  other hand, are statutorily limited to a 45-day cap.Â  See S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§ 8-11-620 (â€œUpon termination from state employment, an employee may take both
  annual leave and a lump-sum payment for unused leave, but this combination may
  not exceed forty-five days in a calendar yearâ€).
We
  find Duvallâ€™s arguments unpersuasive.Â  The statutory language defining average
  final compensation clearly indicates that a maximum of 45 daysâ€™ pay for unused
  annual leave should be used to calculate the average final compensation.Â  Thus,
  even if additional payments for annual leave are made at a time other than â€œat
  retirement,â€ those payments should not be included.Â  In our opinion, the
  Legislatureâ€™s inclusion of the terms â€œtermination payâ€ and â€œat retirementâ€ was
  not futile; instead, when these terms are read in context with the entire
  definition of average final compensation, the language clearly establishes the
  intent to cap how much unused annual leave may be figured into the retirement
  calculation. Â See Hodges v. Rainey, supra (the primary
  rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the
  Legislature); see also South Carolina State Ports Auth. v. Jasper County, supra (a statute should not be construed by focusing on an
  isolated phrase).
Furthermore,
  this Courtâ€™s discussion of average final compensation in Kennedy v. South
    Carolina Ret. Sys., 345 S.C. 339, 549 S.E.2d 243 (2001), supports the
  decision made by the SCRS.[7]Â 
  At issue in Kennedy was whether the 45 days of unused annual leave pay
  should be added into the equation before or after the total average had been
  calculated.Â  The Kennedy Court looked to the legislative history, as
  well as the rules of statutory construction, and concluded the intent was that
  annual leave pay should be added prior to the average being computed.
The Kennedy Court noted that when the Legislature amended this definition in 1978, it â€œaddressed
  unused annual leave for the first time.â€Â  Id. at 344, 549 S.E.2d at
  245.Â  The 1978 amendment added the following emphasized language, and the
  definition then stated as follows:Â  


	â€œAverage final compensationâ€ with respect to those members
  retiring on or after July 1, 1970, shall mean the average annual earnable
  compensation of a member during the three consecutive fiscal years of his
  creditable service producing the highest such average; an amount up to and including forty-five days
    termination pay for unused annual leave may be added to the pay period
    immediately prior to retirement and included in the average as applicable. 
	

Prior
  to 1978, however, there was no language specifically addressing unused annual
  leave.Â  As a matter of policy, the SCRS had credited retirees with all of their accrued unused leave and used that credit when calculating the average
  final compensation.Â  Moreover, there was no limit on the amount of annual leave
  that an employee could accumulate.Â  See id. at 343, 549 S.E.2d at
  245.
According to the Kennedy Court, the 1978
  amendment therefore had two primary effects regarding annual leave:

	First, the amendment placed a
  forty-five day cap on the amount of unused annual leave for which an employee
  could receive credit. Â Second, the unused annual leave could only be calculated
  in the average final compensation equation if the pay period immediately prior
  to the employeeâ€™s retirement was one of the three highest in the employeeâ€™s
  career. Â As a consequence of this second restriction, employees would regularly
  have to retire on the last day of their last fiscal year to ensure that any
  unused annual leave would be included in the calculation.Â  Servicing a large
  volume of retirement claims at one time created an administrative problem for
  the Retirement System.

Id.Â   
As a
  result of this administrative glitch, the Legislature amended the definition
  again in 1986 by using language regarding â€œtwelve consecutive quartersâ€ as
  opposed to â€œthree consecutive fiscal years.â€Â  Thus,
  the 1986 amendment allowed members of the SCRS â€œto retire throughout the
  year, rather than require essentially all retirements to occur on June 30, the
  last day of the fiscal year.â€ Â Wehle, 363 S.C. at 400, 611 S.E.2dÂ  at
  243.
The Kennedy Courtâ€™s conclusion was that average final compensation was properly
  calculated by totaling the 12 highest consecutive quarters, adding the termination
  payment for up to 45 days of unused annual leave, and then taking the
  average.Â  The Court reasoned that if the statute was interpreted as allowing
  the annual leave payment to be added in after an average was taken,
  â€œthis interpretation would increase the dollar value for unused annual leave
  three fold, and would allow members
  to retire with benefits calculated on an â€˜averageâ€™ salary which is greater than
  any salary they earned during employment.â€Â  Kennedy, 345 S.C. at 348,
  549 S.E.2d at 248 (footnote omitted).
In the instant
  case, Duvallâ€™s position is that he is entitled to calculate his average final
  compensation by adding: (1) his pre-retirement payments for over 90 days of excess unused leave ($57,997.76);
  (2) his regular salary for the 12 quarters prior to retirement; and (3) his
  final payment at retirement for 45 days of unused annual leave ($27,637.20);
  and then dividing that sum by three.Â  Clearly, this would inflate the average
  of his final three years of salary to an amount significantly â€œgreater than any
  salaryâ€ he earned during one regular year of employment.Â  Pursuant to Kennedy,
  this would be an absurd result unintended by the Legislature.Â  See id. at 351, 549 S.E.2d at 249 (statutes should not be construed as to lead to
  absurd results).
Put
  another way, Duvall is asking that he be credited with three times the amount
  of unused annual leave that state employees are permitted.Â  We simply do not
  believe the Legislature intended such a result, especially because the language
  of section 9-1-10(4) defines the average final compensation to be for those
  â€œmembers retiring.â€Â  We therefore find that the 45-day cap for unused annual
  leave is intended for all members of the SCRS, not simply those classified as
  state employees. Â Cf. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 9-1-290 (1986) (the Budget and
  Control Board shall, â€œfrom time to time, in its discretion, adopt rules and
  regulations to prevent injustices and inequalities which might otherwise arise
  in the administration of the System.â€).
Finally,
  Duvall contends that an amendment to section 9-1-1020, which expressly supports
  the practice used by the SCRS in this case, was a material change to the
  statute, thereby indicating that his interpretation of the statute (in its
  prior form) is correct.Â  We disagree.
When
  the Legislature adopts an amendment to a statute, this Court recognizes a
  presumption that the Legislature intended to change the existing law.Â  Key
    Corp. Capital, Inc. v. County of Beaufort, 373 S.C. 55, 60, 644 S.E.2d 675,
  678 (2007).Â  Nonetheless, a subsequent statutory amendment may also be
  interpreted as clarifying original legislative intent.Â  Stuckey v. State
    Budget and Control Bd., 339 S.C. 397, 401, 529 S.E.2d 706,
  708 (2000) (citing Cotty v. Yartzeff, 309
  S.C. 259, 422 S.E.2d 100 (1992)).
At
  the time the SCRS made its decision in this case, section 9-1-1020 read as
  follows, in pertinent part:

	Payments
  for unused sick leave, single special payments at retirement, bonus and
  incentive-type payments, or any other payments not considered a part of the
  regular salary base are not compensation for which contributions are
  deductible. Contributions are deductible on pay for unused annual leave.

In 2005, the Legislature amended this section, with an effective
  date of July 1, 2004.Â  See 2005 Act No. 14, Â§ 3 (the Act).Â  The statute
  now provides as follows:

	Payments
  for unused sick leave, single special payments at retirement, bonus and
  incentive-type payments, or any other payments not considered a part of the
  regular salary base are not compensation for which contributions are
  deductible. Â Contributions are deductible on up to and including forty-five
    daysâ€™ termination pay for unused annual leave. Â If a member has received
      termination pay for unused annual leave on more than one occasion,
      contributions are deductible on up to and including forty-five daysâ€™ termination
      pay for unused annual leave for each termination payment for unused annual
      leave received by the member.Â  However, only an amount up to and including
      forty-five daysâ€™ pay for unused annual leave from the memberâ€™s last termination
      payment shall be included in a members average final compensation calculation.

(Additions to statute emphasized).Â 
  The title of the Act specifically stated that the amendment of section 9-1-1020
  â€œrelat[ed] to member contributions for purposes of the South Carolina Retirement
  System â€¦, so as to clarify the contribution requirements on unused annual
    leave and the use of such payments in calculating average final compensation.â€Â 
  (Emphasis added.)
Given that the
  title of the Act itself indicates the amendment was a clarification of, rather
  than a change to, the law, we find a remand to the ALC is unnecessary.Â  See, e.g., Kennedy, 345 S.C. at 349, 549 S.E.2d at 248 (where the
  Court looked at the title of an Act to glean legislative intent); Demas v. Convention Motor Inns, 268 S.C. 186, 190, 232 S.E.2d 724, 726 (1977)
  (noting that it is proper to discern legislative intent from the title of an Act).
CONCLUSION
Based on the above
  discussion, we hold that the circuit court and the ALC correctly decided the
  SCRS appropriately excluded payments made to Duvall for excess unused annual
  leave from the calculation of his retirement benefits.Â  Thus, the circuit courtâ€™s decision is
 
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 9-1-470 (Supp. 2007).
[2] Originally, the SCRS
  subtracted contributions to the retirement system from these payments.Â 
  However, those contributions were subsequently refunded to Duvall.
[3] Duvall had 36 years of service credit within the
  SCRS.Â  Pursuant to the TERI program, Duvall remains director of MASC until
  September 30, 2008.Â  For these five years, the SCRS retains his monthly
  retirement benefits in an interest-free account.
[4] This does not take into account cost of living
  increases.
[5] â€œEarnable compensationâ€ is defined as â€œthe full rate
  of the compensation that would be payable to a member if the member worked the
  memberâ€™s full normal working time; when compensation includes maintenance,
  fees, and other things of value the board shall fix the value of that part of
  the compensation not paid in money directly by the employer.â€Â  Â§ 9-1-10(8).
[6] To support his argument that the payments for excess
  leave should be considered part of his salary, Duvall relies on Bales v.
    Aughtry, 302 S.C. 262, 395 S.E.2d 177 (1990).Â  In Bales, the Court
  stated that â€œ[l]eave benefits are part of compensation earned for services
  rendered and the right to receive that compensation vests once the services are
  rendered.â€Â  Id. at 264, 395 S.E.2d at 179.Â  The issue in Bales,
  however, was not how leave payments related to retirement calculations;
  instead, it was whether elected county officials were entitled to payment of accumulated sick and annual leave.Â  The Court held that
  â€œ[p]ayment for accrued leave benefits
  does not constitute extra compensation after services rendered.â€Â  Id.Â  Here, there is no dispute that Duvall was indeed paid for his accrued leave
  benefits.Â  The issue is whether those payments should be figured into the
  average final compensation computation.Â  Thus, we find Bales inapposite
  to the instant case.
[7] When Kennedy was heard, the statutory section
  defining average final compensation was Â§ 9-1-10(17), but it is now located at Â§
  9-1-10(4).

title: Austin v. Beaufort County Sheriff's Office
description: In this direct appeal, the issue involves a claim for the spoliation of evidence.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Carolyn Bair
      Austin, Individually and as Personal Representative of the Estate of Robert
      Jacob Bair, deceased, Appellant,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Beaufort County Sheriff's Office, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26452
Heard February 6, 2008 - Filed March 10,
  2008Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				M.
  AdamÂ  Gess, of McDaniel & Gess, of Beaufort, Mark Weston Hardee, of the
  Hardee Law Firm, of Columbia, and Robert E. Austin, Jr., of Robert E. Austin,
  Jr., Law Offices, of Leesburg, Florida, for Appellant.
				Marshall
  H. Waldron, Jr., of Bluffton, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE WALLER: This is a
  direct appeal from the trial courtâ€™s order which granted summary judgment in
  favor of respondent, Beaufort County Sheriffâ€™s Office (the Sheriffâ€™s Office).Â 
  We affirm.
FACTS
On July 25, 2001, Robert Bair, the adult son of appellant Carolyn
  Bair Austin, was found dead in his neighborâ€™s garage at a condominium complex
  in Hilton Head.Â  The Sheriffâ€™s Office began an investigation into his death and
  collected the following items from the scene:Â  three blood swabs, one syringe,
  some green leafy vegetable matter,[1] and a white rock substance, which field tested positive for cocaine.Â  In
  addition to this evidence, the Sheriffâ€™s Office submitted four envelopes
  containing photographs.
The
  cause of Bairâ€™s death was determined to be an illegal drug overdose.Â  In July
  2002, the Sheriffâ€™s Office destroyed the items of evidence.Â  In July 2004,
  appellantâ€™s attorney discovered that the evidence, as well as related reports,
  had been destroyed.Â  Appellant filed an action against the Sheriffâ€™s Office
  claiming she is entitled to damages because the destruction of evidence
  impaired her ability to bring a wrongful death action.[2]Â  In an amended complaint, appellant
  explained her theory regarding Bairâ€™s death as follows:Â  â€œOn July 25, 2001,
  decedent was assaulted by unknown assailants who inflicted bodily injuries and
  a fatal dose of drugs on decedent.â€Â   
The
  Sheriffâ€™s Office moved for summary judgment. Â Appellant moved for a continuance
  in order to conduct additional discovery.Â  The trial court granted summary
  judgment for the Sheriffâ€™s Office.Â   
ISSUE

	Did the trial court err in granting summary judgment? 
	

DISCUSSION
Appellant urges this Court to adopt the tort of third party
  spoliation of evidence and allow the case to further proceed through the
  discovery phase. Specifically, she argues we should recognize the spoliation
  tort as outlined by West Virginia in Hannah
    v. Heeter, 584 S.E.2d 560 (W.Va. 2003).Â  Under the facts of this case, we
  decline to do so.
This
  Court reviews the grant of a summary judgment motion under the same
  standard as the trial court, pursuant to Rule 56(c), SCRCP:Â  summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving
  party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law. E.g., Burriss v. Anderson County Bd. of Educ., 369 S.C. 443, 633 S.E.2d 482 (2006); Dawkins v. Fields,
  354 S.C. 58, 580 S.E.2d 433 (2003).Â  The
  purpose of summary judgment is to expedite disposition of cases which do not
  require the services of a fact finder.Â  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C.
  440, 548 S.E.2d 868 (2001).Â   
In Hannah,
  the Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia recognized two â€œstand-alone
  tortsâ€ regarding spoliation of evidence:Â  (1) negligent spoliation of
  evidence by a third party; and (2) intentional spoliation of evidence by
  either a party to the civil action or a third party.[3]
Regarding negligent
  spoliation by a third party, the Hannah court held that the tort had the
  following elements:

	(1) the
  existence of a pending or potential civil action; 
	(2) the
  alleged spoliator had actual knowledge of the pending or potential civil action; 
	(3) a
  duty to preserve evidence arising from a contract, agreement, statute,
  administrative rule, voluntary assumption of duty, or other special
  circumstances; 
	(4)
  spoliation of the evidence; 
	(5) the
  spoliated evidence was vital to a partyâ€™s ability to prevail in a pending or
  potential civil action; and 
	(6)
  damages. 

Hannah, 584 S.E.2d at 569-70.
As for the tort of intentional spoliation of evidence, the Hannah court listed similar elements:

	(1) a
  pending or potential civil action;
	(2)
  knowledge of the spoliator of the pending or potential civil action; 
	
	(3)
  willful destruction of evidence; 
	(4) the
  spoliated evidence was vital to a partyâ€™s ability to prevail in the pending or
  potential civil action; 
	(5) the
  intent of the spoliator to defeat a partyâ€™s ability to prevail in the pending
  or potential civil action; 
	(6) the
  partyâ€™s inability to prevail in the civil action; and 
	(7)
  damages. 

Hannah, 584 S.E.2d at 573.Â   
Under the
  particular facts of the instant case, it is clear that appellantâ€™s allegations
  do not rise to the level of stating a claim.Â  First, although appellant
  contends there is a potential wrongful death action, no tortfeasor has been
  identified, beyond the â€œunknown assailantsâ€ mentioned in the complaint.Â 
  Therefore, it is merely speculative that a potential civil action for wrongful
  death exists.Â  Second, it obviously follows that the Sheriffâ€™s Office, could
  not have actually known of the potentiality of a lawsuit, especially given the
  fact that the Sheriffâ€™s Office apparently concluded that Bairâ€™s drug overdose
  had been self-inflicted.Â  Certainly, appellant never notified the Sheriffâ€™s
  Office of the fact that she sought to pursue a civil lawsuit related to her
  sonâ€™s death.
Third, appellant
  can point to no specific duty that the Sheriffâ€™s Office was required to
  preserve this evidence.Â  We have held in a criminal case that the State has no
  absolute duty to preserve potentially useful evidence that might exonerate a
  defendant. Â See State v. Cheeseboro, 346 S.C. 526, 538-39, 552 S.E.2d
  300, 307 (2001).Â  Clearly, then, under the facts of the instant case, there
  was no general duty to preserve evidence after the police had terminated a
  criminal investigation.
Finally, because of
  the speculative nature regarding the value of the evidence destroyed, appellant
  is simply unable to establish that the destroyed evidence was vital to her
  ability to prevail in the potential civil action.Â   
Accordingly,
  even using the tort elements set out by the Hannah court as urged by appellant,
  no claim for third party spoliation of evidence has been alleged.Â  Thus, we
  decline to address whether we would, under other factual circumstances, adopt
  the tort of third party spoliation of evidence.Â  The grant of summary judgment
  in favor of the Sheriffâ€™s Office is
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] This material was believed to be marijuana.
[2] Appellant has not alleged the Sheriffâ€™s Office is
  responsible for Bairâ€™s death.
[3] The court refused to recognize first party negligent
  spoliation of evidence.

title: Grosshuesch v. Cramer
description: This case consolidates several discovery-related appeals in a civil action, and the issues on appeal deal primarily with the invocation of the Fifth Amendmentâ€™s privilege against compelled self-incrimination.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				An L.
      Grosshuesch, Guardian and Conservator of Eleanor A. Breedlove, and An L.
      Grosshuesch, Guardian and Conservator of Bernard H. Breedlove, Respondents/Appellants,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Lisa Cramer,
      Nathan Cramer, Lawrence H. Gray, Jr., Duane Marie Gray, and Sweetgrass Land
      Company, LLC, Defendants,
				of whom Lisa
      Cramer is Appellant/Respondent.
			
		
	

and

	
		
			
				Ex Parte:
      Charles B. Macloskie, Appellant,
				In 
				Re: An L. Grosshuesch, Guardian and Conservator of Eleanor A. Breedlove, and An L.
      Grosshuesch, Guardian and Conservator of Bernard H. Breedlove, Respondents,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Lisa Cramer,
      Nathan Cramer, Lawrence H. Gray, Jr., Duane Marie Gray, and Sweetgrass Land
      Company, LLC, Defendants.
			
		
	

and

	
		
			
				An L.
      Grosshuesch, Guardian and Conservator of Eleanor A. Breedlove, and An L.
      Grosshuesch, Guardian and Conservator of Bernard H. Breedlove, Appellants,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Lisa Cramer,
      Nathan Cramer, Lawrence H. Gray, Jr., Daune Marie Gray, and Sweetgrass Land
      Company, LLC, Respondents.
			
		
	

and

	
		
			
				Ex Parte: Â Lionel
      S. Lofton, Appellant,
				In Re:Â  An L.
      Grosshuesch, Guardian and Conservator of Eleanor A. Breedlove, and An L.
      Grosshuesch, Guardian and Conservator of Bernard H. Breedlove, Respondents,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Lisa Cramer,
      Nathan Cramer, Lawrence H. Gray, Jr., Duane Marie Gray, and Sweetgrass Land
      Company, LLC, Defendants.
			
		
	


Appeals from Beaufort and Charleston Counties
Curtis L. Coltrane, Circuit Court Judge
Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No.Â  26453
Heard January 9, 2008 - Filed March 10,
  2008Â  
VACATED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART,
  DISMISSED IN PART 


	
		
			
				Lionel
  S. Lofton and V. Lynn Lofton, both of Lofton & Lofton, of Charleston, and Charles
  B. Macloskie, of the Macloskie Law Firm, of Beaufort, for Appellant/Respondent
  Lisa Cramer and for Appellants Lofton and Macloskie.
				Richard
  S. Rosen and Andrew D. Gowdown, both of Rosen, Rosen & Hagood, of Charleston, for Respondents/Appellants.
			
		
	


CHIEF
  JUSTICE TOAL:Â  These consolidated
  appeals relate to several discovery orders in a civil action.Â  Bernard and
  Eleanor Breedlove initiated the underlying lawsuit seeking to set aside several
  transfers of assets to Lisa and Nathan Cramer on the grounds of fraud and undue
  influence.Â  The parties contest several issues on appeal, but the foremost is whether
  the trial court erred in imposing discovery-related sanctions on Lisa Cramer.Â  The
  Cramers argue that the trial court should not have imposed sanctions, and the
  Breedloves argue that the trial court should have imposed more.Â  Additionally, the
  Cramersâ€™ attorneys argue that the trial court erred in requiring them to
  produce documents and information relating to the location of assets allegedly transferred
  from the Breedloves, and the Breedloves argue that the trial court erred in issuing
  a protective order making discovery in the case confidential.Â   
Though
  these issues are couched as different types of discovery disputes, they deal primarily
  with the Cramersâ€™ invocation of the privilege against self-incrimination found
  in the Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution.Â  Because we find that
  the trial court did not apply the proper standard when judging the Cramersâ€™ invocation
  of the Fifth Amendment, we vacate the trial courtâ€™s imposition of discovery-related
  sanctions on Lisa Cramer.Â  Similarly, we find that the trial court erred in
  ordering the Cramersâ€™ attorneys to produce documents and information which
  relate to their representation of the Cramers.Â  The remaining questions on
  appeal, specifically, whether the trial court erred in declining to impose
  additional sanctions on Lisa Cramer and whether the trial court erred in
  issuing a protective order, are not immediately appealable and are therefore
  dismissed.

Factual/Procedural Background
The
  Breedloves are elderly individuals with substantial assets who reside in Hilton
  Head, South Carolina.Â  In their complaint, the Breedloves alleged that they
  became acquainted with Lisa Cramer through her employment at the Breedlovesâ€™
  bank, and that after learning of the Breedlovesâ€™ substantial wealth, the
  Cramers conspired to develop an enduring relationship with the Breedloves and
  to exploit that relationship for financial gain.Â  The Breedloves alleged that
  over time, they transferred several million dollars worth of real estate and
  liquid assets to the Cramers.Â  During the time of these transfers, the
  Breedloves were allegedly suffering from some degree of dementia related to
  their advanced age.Â  The Beaufort County Probate Court appointed An L.
  Grosshuesch as guardian and conservator for the Breedloves after the Breedloves
  commenced this lawsuit. Â 
This
  appeal represents the third time this Court has addressed issues arising out of
  this litigation.Â  As their first step in defending the lawsuit, the Cramers
  requested that the trial court stay the suit pending the resolution of the
  criminal actions filed against them relating to these conveyances.Â  The trial
  court denied this request, and we dismissed the Cramersâ€™ appeal from the denial
