JUSTICE BEATTY:Â 
  In this post-conviction relief (PCR) case, the Court granted the Stateâ€™s
  petition for a writ of certiorari to review the PCR judgeâ€™s decision granting
  relief with respect to Patrick Delvon Harrisâ€™s conviction for armed robbery and
  sentence of imprisonment for life without parole (LWOP).Â  We reverse.
FACTS
At
  approximately 12:00 a.m. on March 26, 1998, Jessie Brown and Kevin Outen,
  employees with Park Place Video in Columbia, observed an African-American male
  walk through the video poker establishment and leave after staying only a few
  minutes.Â  Both employees believed the man was â€œscoping outâ€ the place.  
According
  to Brown, the same man returned at 2:00 a.m.Â  At that time, Outen was on the
  phone with the store manager.Â  Outen â€œbuzzed inâ€ the man unaware that he was
  accompanied by two masked men.Â  As the men â€œrushedâ€ in, one of the masked men
  pointed a gun at Outen and ordered him to hang up the phone and get on the
  floor.Â  Outen complied but left the phone on the counter so that the manager
  could hear what was transpiring in the store.Â  The other masked man ordered
  Brown at gunpoint to show him where the store kept the money.Â  The man then
  took the money and handed it to one of his accomplices.Â  Outen was then led by
  one of the masked men to a back room where two customers had been playing video
  poker.Â  After hearing the commotion, the customers hid in the room and locked
  the door.Â  The masked man kicked open the door and ordered Outen and the two
  customers at gunpoint to get on the ground and remain in the room.Â  While they
  were in the room, the three captives heard several gunshots before the robbers
  exited the store.Â  Shortly after the gunshots ended, one of the customers heard
  a car drive off.
According
  to Brown, the men â€œtore the place upâ€ and then fired several gunshots before
  leaving.Â  Brown identified the man that accosted him as the last man to leave
  the premises.Â  He described this man as wearing a mask, a dark brown leather
  coat, and black leather pants.Â  Â Â 
When
  Brown emerged from one of the back rooms, deputies with the Richland County
  Sheriffâ€™s Department were already on the scene having been summoned by a 911
  call placed by the store manager who heard the commotion while speaking with
  Outen on the telephone.Â   
Deputies
  Ray Livingston and Jason Christophel, who were separately patrolling the Parklane Road area, responded to the call within less than a minute.Â  When they arrived,
  they observed a masked man wearing black pants and a dark leather jacket exit
  the store and then flee the scene.Â  Deputy Christophel pursued the suspect on
  foot while Deputy Livingston attempted to apprehend the suspect by driving
  around the adjacent area.Â  Ultimately, Deputy Christophel apprehended and
  arrested the suspect within a few minutes.Â  According to Deputies Christophel
  and Livingston, the suspect, who was identified as Harris, said â€œYou got me. I
  did it. You got meâ€ as they were arresting him. Â The deputies then transported
  Harris back to the scene where they retrieved the mask that he had discarded as
  he exited the store.Â  At the store, Harris told the officers that the other men
  had absconded in a burgundy-colored Thunderbird and gave the license plate
  number.
The
  deputies then transported Harris to the Richland County Sheriffâ€™s Department
  where he was interviewed by Investigators Eric Barnes and Stephen Curtis.Â 
  According to Barnes and Curtis, Harris gave an oral statement in which he
  admitted his involvement in the armed robbery but declined to provide
  additional details.Â  Eventually, Harris identified his accomplices as Stuart
  Young and Walter Lewis.Â  The investigators also questioned Brown, Outen, the
  store manager, and the two customers regarding their account of the robbery.
 
With this
  information, the investigators compiled a photographic lineup and presented it to Outen.Â  Outen was able to identify Stuart Young as the robber who did not wear
  a mask.Â  The next day, the investigators arrested Young after they apprehended
  him while he was driving Harrisâ€™s Thunderbird.Â  Young gave a written statement
  to the investigators in which he admitted his involvement in the robbery and
  implicated Harris and Lewis.Â  Lewis, who left the state after the robbery, was
  ultimately taken into custody after he was arrested in Virginia on unrelated
  federal charges.
On March 15, 1999, Harris
  was tried for armed robbery before Circuit Court Judge John Breeden.Â  Because the
  jury could not reach a verdict, this trial ended in a mistrial. Â Harris was retried
  on March 30, 1999.[1]Â 
  At the conclusion of the second trial before Circuit Court Judge James C.
  Williams, Jr., Harris was convicted of armed robbery and sentenced to life
  imprisonment without parole pursuant to section 17-25-45 of the South Carolina
  Code due to his nine prior convictions for armed robbery.[2]Â 
  On direct appeal, this Court affirmed Harrisâ€™s conviction and sentence in State
    v. Harris, Op. No. 2001-MO-021 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Mar. 28, 2001). 
 
Subsequently,
  Harris filed an application for post-conviction relief, alleging he was being
  held unlawfully due to:Â  ineffective assistance of trial counsel; lack of
  subject matter jurisdiction; a sentence which violated ex post facto laws; and
  a sentence which violated Article XII, Â§ 2 of the South Carolina Constitution.
 
Circuit Court Judge
  G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., held a hearing on Harrisâ€™s petition.Â  At the hearing,
  Harrisâ€™s PCR counsel contended trial counsel was ineffective in that he failed
  to:Â  (1) procure a copy of the trial transcript from Harrisâ€™s first trial or
  move for a continuance until such transcript could be obtained; (2) have Harris
  served with sufficient legal notice of the Stateâ€™s intention to seek LWOP; and
  (3) adequately consult with Harris prior to the two trials.Â  Additionally, PCR
  counsel alleged that appellate counsel was ineffective for failing to brief
  Harrisâ€™s motion to relieve trial counsel.Â  In support of these allegations, PCR
  counsel called Harris and his trial counsel, James Mann, as witnesses.
After the hearing,
  Judge Cooper issued an order granting Harrisâ€™s application for post-conviction
  relief.Â  In reaching this decision, Judge Cooper found trial counsel was
  ineffective and Harris was prejudiced by counselâ€™s failure to procure a copy of
  the first trial transcript.Â  Because there were â€œobvious inconsistencies in
  crucial testimony,â€ Judge Cooper believed trial counsel should have obtained
  the transcript to prove these â€œsubstantial differences.â€Â  Secondly, Judge
  Cooper found that counselâ€™s pre-trial consultation with Harris was inadequate
  given the State was seeking a sentence of LWOP.Â  Finally, Judge Cooper
  concluded Harrisâ€™s LWOP sentence was void because there was no evidence that
  Harris had been served with written notice of the Stateâ€™s intent to seek a
  sentence of LWOP as mandated by the terms of section 17-25-45(H).
This
  Court granted the Stateâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari to review the PCR judgeâ€™s
  decision.
DISCUSSION
A
  defendant has the right to the effective assistance of counsel under the Sixth
  Amendment to the United States Constitution.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984).Â  â€œThere is a strong presumption that counsel rendered
  adequate assistance and exercised reasonable professional judgment in making
  all significant decisions in the case.â€Â  Ard v. Catoe, 372 S.C. 318,
  331, 642 S.E.2d 590, 596 (2007), cert. denied, 128 S. Ct. 370 (2007).Â Â  
 
In a
  PCR proceeding, the applicant bears the burden of establishing that he is
  entitled to relief.Â  Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 109, 525 S.E.2d
  514, 517 (2000).Â  In order to prove that counsel was ineffective, the PCR
  applicant must show that: (1) counselâ€™s performance was deficient; and (2)
  there is a reasonable probability that, but for counselâ€™s errors, the result of
  the trial would have been different.Â  Id. (citing Strickland v.
    Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984)).Â  â€œA reasonable probability is a
  probability sufficient to undermine confidence in the outcome of the trial.â€Â  Ard,
  372 S.C. at 331, 642 S.E.2d at 596. â€œFurthermore, when a defendantâ€™s conviction
  is challenged, â€˜the question is whether there is a reasonable probability that,
  absent the errors, the fact finder would have had a reasonable doubt respecting
  guilt.â€™â€ Id. (quoting Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 695 (1984)).
â€œThis
  Court gives great deference to the post-conviction relief (PCR) courtâ€™s
  findings of fact and conclusions of law.â€Â  Dempsey v. State, 363 S.C.
  365, 368, 610 S.E.2d 812, 814 (2005).Â  A PCR courtâ€™s findings will be upheld on
  appeal if there is â€œany evidence of probative value sufficient to support
  them.â€Â  Id.Â  This Court will reverse the PCR courtâ€™s decision when it is
  controlled by an error
  of law.Â  Sheppard v. State, 357 S.C. 646, 651, 594 S.E.2d 462, 465
  (2004).
I.
The
  State contends the PCR judge erred in finding trial counsel was ineffective in
  failing to consult with Harris prior to both trials.Â  We agree with the Stateâ€™s
  contention.
In
  granting Harris relief on this ground, the PCR judge found Harrisâ€™s allegations
  that his meetings with counsel were â€œlimited in number and durationâ€ and that
  he never received a copy of the discovery materials were â€œmainly unrefuted by
  trial counsel.â€ Â Specifically, the judge noted that trial counsel did not know
  exactly how many times he had met with Harris to prepare for trial or whether
  he had provided Harris with the discovery materials.Â  The PCR judge also found
  significant the fact that counsel did not produce any time records to document
  his preparation with Harris.Â  The PCR judge stated that â€œ[b]ased upon the lack
  of evidence to the contrary, the Court would have to conclude that trial
  counselâ€™s preparation with his client in a case involving life without parole
  was inadequate and constitutes ineffective assistance of counsel.â€  
At
  the PCR hearing, Harris testified he met with trial counsel two or three times
  prior to the first trial.Â  He also admitted that trial counsel reviewed the
  discovery materials with him for approximately thirty minutes during his first
  visit. Â Harris, however, stated counsel never gave him a copy of these
  materials.Â  Harris also claimed he did not meet with counsel during the ten
  days between the mistrial and the second trial and he had no opportunity to
  discuss trial strategy with counsel prior to the second trial.Â   
In
  contrast, trial counsel testified he was retained by Harrisâ€™s family and began
  preparing for the case in late December 1998 after he mailed a Rule 5 motion to
  the solicitorâ€™s office.Â  After he received the discovery materials, counsel
  â€œessentially treated [Harrisâ€™s mandatory life case] like . . . the death
  penalty appointments [he] had in the past, which is that [he] just put
  everything else down.â€Â  Counsel could not recall how many times he met with Harris
  prior to the first trial; however, he stated â€œthereâ€™s no question in my mind
  that I had completely mastered the defenseâ€ and â€œwas prepared on what we had to
  do on [Harrisâ€™s] part.â€Â  Counsel also stated that he went over all the
  discovery materials with Harris prior to trial.Â  Although counsel could not
  remember whether he left a copy of the discovery materials with Harris, he
  testified his routine practice was to leave a copy with his client.Â   
In
  terms of preparation for the second trial, counsel admitted that he did not
  meet with Harris between the two trials.Â  However, he testified he met with the
  solicitorâ€™s office at least three times in an attempt to negotiate a plea
  agreement for Harris.Â  Counsel also stated that he did not try another case in
  between the two trials and believed the facts of the case were fresh on his
  mind during the second trial.Â  He also noted there were no additions to the
  discovery materials between the first and second trials.  
We
  find the PCR judgeâ€™s conclusion that trial counselâ€™s preparation was inadequate
  is not supported by the evidence in the record.Â  Notably, counsel testified he
  had been practicing law for approximately thirty years and that half of his
  practice involved criminal cases.Â  Presumably, â€œcounsel rendered adequate
  assistance and exercised reasonable professional judgment in making all
  significant decisions in the case.â€Â  Ard v. Catoe, 372 S.C. 318, 331,
  642 S.E.2d 590, 596 (2007), cert. denied, 128 S. Ct. 370 (2007).
Additionally,
  we believe trial counselâ€™s testimony refutes Harrisâ€™s allegations and directly
  contradicts the PCR judgeâ€™s finding.Â  See Scott v. State,
  334 S.C. 248, 252, 513 S.E.2d 100, 102 (1999) (stating â€œan appellate court will not affirm the
  decision when it is not supported by any probative evidenceâ€).Â  First, there is
  no question that counsel met with Harris on several occasions prior to the
  first trial.Â  Even if the meetings were brief, this fact alone is not
  indicative of inadequate trial preparation.Â  See Easter v. Estelle,
  609 F.2d 756, 759 (5th Cir. 1980) (recognizing that brevity of time spent in
  consultation with defendant, without more, did not establish that trial counsel
  was ineffective).Â   
Furthermore, Harris did not offer any evidence or argument as to
  how counselâ€™s alleged lack of preparation prejudiced him.Â  Therefore, it is
  merely speculative that counselâ€™s alleged deficient performance was prejudicial
  to Harris.Â  See Glover v. State, 318 S.C. 496, 498, 458 S.E.2d
  538, 540 (1995) (noting mere speculation and conjecture on the part of
  Respondent is insufficient to substantiate allegation that counselâ€™s deficient performance
  was prejudicial to respondent).Â   
Finally, the PCR judge failed to make a finding regarding how the
  outcome of the trial would have been different had counsel spent more time with
  Harris or given him a copy of the discovery materials.Â  See Jackson
    v. State, 329 S.C. 345, 353-54, 495 S.E.2d 768, 772 (1998) (finding PCR
  judge erred in finding counsel ineffective in preparing respondentâ€™s case where
  respondent failed to show how his counselâ€™s lack of preparation prejudiced him
  given respondent did not â€œpresent any evidence of what counsel could have
  discovered or what other defenses respondent would have requested counsel
  pursue had counsel more fully prepared for the trialâ€); Davis v. State,
  326 S.C. 283, 288, 486 S.E.2d 747, 749 (1997) (holding record did not support
  PCR judgeâ€™s conclusion that counselâ€™s deficient performance was prejudicial to respondent
  given respondent did not show how additional preparation would have resulted in
  a different outcome); Skeen v. State, 325 S.C. 210, 214, 481 S.E.2d 129,
  132 (1997) (finding applicant was not entitled to post-conviction relief where
  there was no evidence presented at the PCR hearing to show how additional preparation
  would have had any possible effect on the result of the trial). Accordingly, we
  hold the PCR judge erred in finding that counselâ€™s preparation was inadequate
  and constituted a ground for granting Harris post-conviction relief.Â   
II.
The
  State argues the PCR judge erred in finding trial counsel was ineffective in
  failing to obtain a transcript from Harrisâ€™s first trial in order to impeach
  witnesses during the second trial.Â  We agree.
Because
  trial counsel did not obtain the transcript, the PCR judge found counsel could
  not effectively present Harrisâ€™s defense at the second trial.Â  In the judgeâ€™s
  view, having a copy of the first trial transcript was critical to Harrisâ€™s
  defense given: Â the first case ended in a mistrial; there was not overwhelming evidence
  of guilt; and there were discrepancies in several witnessesâ€™ testimonies
  presented at the first and second trials.Â   
For
  several reasons, we conclude the PCR judge erred in granting Harris relief on
  this ground.Â  As an initial matter, Harris never presented a copy of the
  transcript at the PCR hearing.Â  Although the audiotapes from the first trial
  had been destroyed by the time of the hearing, Harris, on at least two
  occasions, wrote to the Richland County Clerk of Court approximately one month
  after his second trial requesting a transcript from each trial.Â  Additionally, we
  believe Harrisâ€™s PCR counsel, who was appointed within three years of the
  mistrial, could have requested the transcript before the audiotapes were
  destroyed in accordance with the version of Rule 607(i), SCACR, which was in
  effect at the time of the PCR hearing.Â  See Rule 607(i), SCACR (â€œ[A]
  court reporter shall retain the primary and backup tapes of a proceeding for a
  period of at least three years (3) after the date of the proceeding, and the
  court reporter may reuse or destroy the tapes after the expiration of that
  period.â€).[3]Â  Â Â 
Because
  it was incumbent upon Harris to provide the PCR judge with a copy of the
  transcript in order to show that he was prejudiced by its absence at the second
  trial, Harris did not meet his burden to prove that trial counsel was deficient
  and that the result of his trial would have been different but for this alleged
  deficiency.Â  It was merely speculative that the transcript would have aided in
  his defense. Â See Palacio v. State, 333 S.C. 506, 513, 511 S.E.2d
  62, 66 (1999) (finding that where contents of challenged documents were not
  presented at the PCR hearing, defendant failed to present any evidence of
  probative value demonstrating how counselâ€™s failure to obtain the unproduced
  documents in a more timely fashion prejudiced his defense); cf. Porter
    v. State, 368 S.C. 378, 386, 629 S.E.2d 353, 358 (2006) (â€œMere speculation
  of what a witnessâ€™ testimony may be is insufficient to satisfy the burden of showing
  prejudice in a petition for PCR.â€); Dempsey v. State, 363 S.C. 365, 369,
  610 S.E.2d 812, 814 (2005) (â€œA PCR applicant cannot show that he was prejudiced
  by counselâ€™s failure to call a favorable witness to testify at trial if that
  witness does not later testify at the PCR hearing or otherwise offer testimony
  within the rules of evidence.â€).
Even
  if Harris met his burden to show that counsel was deficient in failing to
  obtain the transcript, Harris did not prove this alleged deficiency prejudiced
  his defense.Â  First, trial counsel testified at the PCR hearing that in
  preparing for the second trial he concentrated on the notes he had from every
  witness that testified at the first trial, the notes of his opening statement
  and closing argument, as well as his notes from his cross-examinations. Â Because
  he did not try another case in between Harrisâ€™s two trials, counsel believed
  the events of the first trial were fresh in his mind during the second trial.Â  Additionally,
  counsel explained he did not order the first trial transcript because he did
  not believe having the transcript would be important in terms of
  cross-examining the Stateâ€™s witnesses.  
In
  terms of specific testimony, counsel believed the only critical difference in
  testimony between the two trials was that of Investigator Barnes.Â  Counsel
  explained that during the first trial, in an in camera hearing, Investigator
  Barnes was uncertain whether Harris admitted his involvement at the time he
  revealed the identities of Young and Lewis.Â  In the second trial, Investigator
  Barnes admitted he made an error in his prior testimony in that he believed
  Harris did in fact admit to his involvement in the robbery.Â   
In
  conjunction with this testimony, trial counsel also acknowledged there were
  differences in Deputy Livingstonâ€™s testimony during the first and second
  trials.Â  Counsel, however, emphasized that his cross-examination of Deputy
  Livingston pointed out the difference in testimony regarding the statement
  Harris made when he was apprehended by Deputies Livingston and Christophel.Â  In
  the first trial, Deputy Livingston testified that Harris only stated â€œYou got
  me;â€ however, in the second trial, he claimed that Harris stated â€œYou got me.Â 
  I did it. You got me.â€Â   
We
  find the fact that counsel did not obtain a transcript to impeach Livingston and Barnes was inconsequential. Deputy Christophel testified that Harris
  admitted his involvement in the robbery at the time he was apprehended.Â 
  Specifically, Deputy Christophel testified that Harris stated, â€œYouâ€™ve got me.Â 
  I did it.Â  You got meâ€ at the time he was being handcuffed.Â  Because Deputy
  Christophel was only called as a witness during the second trial, Harrisâ€™s
  counsel could not have impeached him with a prior transcript.Â  Given this
  testimony was essentially the same as that of Deputies Livingston and Barnes, we
  find a copy of the transcript was not critical in presenting Harrisâ€™s defense.
III.
The
  State asserts the PCR judge erred in granting relief where Harris was unable to
  show prejudice from counselâ€™s failure to obtain the transcript due to the
  overwhelming evidence supporting Harrisâ€™s guilt.Â  We agree with the Stateâ€™s
  assertion.
The
  evidence presented at trial established that Deputies Livingston and
  Christophel arrived at the scene of the robbery within less than a minute of
  receiving the 911 dispatch.Â  When they arrived, they observed Harris discard
  his mask and then flee the scene.Â  The deputies were able to apprehend Harris
  within minutes at a nearby location.Â  According to Christophel and Livingston,
  Harris immediately admitted his involvement in the robbery.Â  After being
  transported to the Richland County Sherriffâ€™s Department, Harris again admitted
  his involvement and identified the names of his accomplices.Â  He also informed
  the investigators that these individuals drove away from the scene in his car.Â 
  Harris then gave the investigators the license plate number of the vehicle.Â 
  Additionally, Stuart Young, one of Harrisâ€™s accomplices, was arrested while
  driving Harrisâ€™s car.Â  Shortly thereafter, Outen selected Young out of a
  photographic lineup as the man who was not wearing a mask during the robbery.Â  In
  his written statement and trial testimony, Young implicated Harris in the armed
  robbery.
Based
  on the foregoing, we find there was overwhelming evidence of Harrisâ€™s guilt.Â 
  Therefore, we hold the PCR judge erred in finding counsel was ineffective in
  failing to obtain a transcript of the first trial in order to impeach the
  witnesses.Â  See Franklin v. Catoe, 346 S.C. 563, 570 n.3, 552
  S.E.2d 718, 722 n.3 (2001), cert. denied, 535 U.S. 1114 (2002) (finding
  overwhelming evidence of guilt negated any claim that counselâ€™s deficient
  performance could have reasonably affected the result of defendantâ€™s trial); Geter
    v. State, 305 S.C. 365, 367, 409 S.E.2d 344, 346 (1991) (concluding reasonable probability of a different
  result does not exist when there is overwhelming evidence of guilt); cf. Ford
    v. State, 314 S.C. 245, 248, 442 S.E.2d 604, 606 (1994)
  (holding respondent failed to prove prejudice from trial counselâ€™s failure to
  request an alibi charge where there was overwhelming evidence of guilt).
IV.
The
  State argues the PCR judge erred in granting a new trial based on the Stateâ€™s
  failure to provide Harris with written notice of its intention to seek a LWOP
  sentence.Â  We agree with the State.
In
  ruling that Harrisâ€™s sentence was void, the PCR judge relied on the Court of
  Appealsâ€™ decision in State v. Johnson, 347 S.C. 67, 552 S.E.2d 339 (Ct.
  App. 2001).Â  In Johnson, the Court of Appeals interpreted the
  requirements of imposing a sentence under section 17-25-45.Â  The court found
  that a LWOP sentence could not be imposed unless written notice of intent to
  seek this sentence was given to both the defendant and defense counsel.Â 
  Recently, this Court overruled Johnson in James v. State, 372
  S.C. 287, 641 S.E.2d 899 (2007), and held that at least ten daysâ€™ actual notice
  is all that is required to impose a LWOP sentence.Â   
In
  the instant case, Harris had at least ten daysâ€™ actual notice of the potential
  LWOP sentence.Â  Prior to his second trial, the trial judge informed Harris that
  he would receive a mandatory LWOP sentence if convicted.Â  Harris acknowledged
  that a LWOP sentence would be imposed.Â  Shortly thereafter, Harris moved to
  have his trial counsel relieved.Â  As the basis for this motion, Harris
  expressed concern with counselâ€™s representation given he was â€œfacing a life
  sentence.â€Â  Additionally, at sentencing the solicitor entered into evidence a
  copy of the Stateâ€™s Notice of Intent to Seek Life without Parole, which had been
  filed on February 26, 1999.Â  The filing of this notice was well in advance of
  Harrisâ€™s two trials, which were conducted on March 15, 1999, and March 30,
  1999.Â  Moreover, at the PCR hearing, trial counsel testified that he had received
  a copy of the Stateâ€™s LWOP notice and that it was part of his file. Â Although
  he did not know for certain whether Harris received a copy of the Stateâ€™s LWOP
  notice, trial counsel testified there was â€œ[n]o question he was informed from
  the get-go that he was facing life imprisonment, mandatory.â€Â  Accordingly, we
  find the PCR judge erred in holding Harrisâ€™s LWOP sentence was void. See Sheppard
    v. State, 357 S.C. 646, 651,
  594 S.E.2d 462, 465 (2004) (noting this Court will reverse the PCR courtâ€™s
  decision when it is controlled by an error of law); see alsoÂ  Scott v. State,
  334 S.C. 248, 252, 513 S.E.2d 100, 102 (1999) (stating â€œan appellate court will not affirm the
  decision when it is not supported by any probative evidenceâ€); Dempsey
    v. State, 363 S.C. 365, 368, 610 S.E.2d 812, 814 (2005) (A
  PCR courtâ€™s findings will be upheld on appeal if there is â€œany evidence of
  probative value sufficient to support them.â€).  
CONCLUSION
In view of the foregoing, we hold the PCR
  judge erred in granting Harrisâ€™s application for post-conviction relief.Â 
  Accordingly, we reverse the order of the PCR judge.
REVERSED.Â  
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  At the beginning of this trial, Harris moved to have
  his trial counsel relieved.Â  Harris claimed to have â€œconflictsâ€ with counsel
  and was concerned about his representation given he was facing a life sentence. 
 
[2]Â Â  Section 17-25-45 permits the State to seek a
  sentence of life without the possibility of parole if the person has one or
  more prior convictions for a â€œmost serious offense,â€ which includes the offense
  of armed robbery.Â Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45(A)(1), (C)(1) (2003 & Supp.
  2007).Â   
[3]Â Â  The current version of Rule 607(i) requires court
  reporters to retain their tapes for a period of at least five years.

title: Amendments to Appendix A to Rule 402, SCACR
description: This is an order amending Appendix A to Rule 402, SCACR.
text:
The Supreme Court of South Carolina



The Supreme Court of South Carolina
RE:	Amendments to Appendix A to Rule 402, SCACR
Rules of the Board of Law Examiners

ORDER

Pursuant to Article V, § 4 of the South Carolina Constitution, the Rules of the Board of Law Examiners, Appendix A to Rule 402, SCACR, are amended as follows.
The title to the Rules of the Board of Law Examiners is amended to read:
APPENDIX A.
  RULES OF THE BOARD OF LAW EXAMINERS
  (Promulgated Pursuant to Rule 402(a)(4), SCACR)
 Additionally, Rule A(3) is amended to read:

  3.	Questions requiring essay type answers will be given on 
    Monday and Tuesday of each examination.  The essay portion of 
    the examination may cover any of the following subjects: 
    Corporations, Agency and Partnership, State and Federal Civil 
    Practice and Procedure, Uniform Commercial Code – Articles 2, 
    3, 4, and 9, Equity, Legal Writing and Research, Wills, Trusts 
    and Estates, Trial Advocacy, Domestic Relations, and Insurance. 
    An applicant should be familiar with principles of law which 
    prevail in this State with respect to the foregoing subjects and any 
    aspects of the law which are peculiar to this State.  The grade an 
    applicant receives will be based both upon the candidate’s 
    knowledge of the applicable law as well as the candidate’s ability 
    to analyze and apply the law to the facts set forth in the questions.

 These amendments shall take effect ninety (90) days from the date of this order.  See Rule 402(a)(4), SCACR.
 IT IS SO ORDERED. 

  
    
     s/Jean H. Toal                                    C.J.
              
              s/James E. Moore                             J.
              
              s/John H. Waller, Jr.                           J.
              
              s/Costa M. Pleicones                        J.
            s/Donald W. Beatty                            J.
    
  

Columbia, South Carolina
March 5, 2008

title: In the Matter of Jeffrey T. Spell
description: This order reinstates Jeffrey T. Spell to the practice of law subject to certain conditions.

The Supreme Court of South Carolina



The Supreme Court of South Carolina
In the Matter of Jeffrey T. Spell, Petitioner.

ORDER

On March 12, 2007, petitioner was suspended from the practice of law for one year, retroactive to August 24, 2005.  In the Matter of Spell, 372 S.C. 514, 642 S.E.2d 749 (2007).  Petitioner has filed a petition for reinstatement.  The Committee on Character and Fitness recommends the petition be granted, subject to the condition that petitioner establish a mentoring relationship with a member of the South Carolina Bar with at least ten years of experience in the practice of real estate law and that the mentor review petitioner’s practices and procedures with regard to his real estate practice and provide reports to the Office of Disciplinary Counsel six months and twelve months after petitioner’s reinstatement.  We grant the petition, subject to the condition set forth by the Committee on Character and Fitness, and reinstate petitioner to the practice of law in South Carolina.
 IT IS SO ORDERED.

title: Inlet Harbour v. SC Department of Parks, Recreation and Tourism
description: This case deals with the scope of an easement over a private road implied in a deed from Respondent Inlet Harbour, a South Carolina general partnership, to the South Carolina Department of Parks, Recreation and Tourism.  The trial court held that the implied easement was limited in scope, the Department of Parks, Recreation and Tourism appealed, and the Court affirmed.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Inlet 
				Harbour, a South Carolina General Partnership, Respondent,
				v.
				The South Carolina Department of Parks, Recreation and Tourism, Appellant,
				v.
				Inlet Harbour
      Property Owners Association, Inc., Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal from Georgetown County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26459
Heard February 7, 2008 - Filed March 17,
  2008Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Mark
  Andrew Nappier, of Joye, Nappier & Risher, of Murrells Inlet, James B. Richardson, Jr., of Columbia, and Ezizze Davis Foxworth, of Loris, for Appellant.
				Dominic
  A. Starr, of Nelson Mullins Riley & Scarborough, of Myrtle Beach, for
  Respondents.
			
		
	


CHIEF
  JUSTICE TOAL:Â  This appeal arises out
  of a dispute involving road access to oceanfront property in Murrells Inlet, South Carolina.Â  The crux of this matter is the scope of an easement over a private road implied
  in a deed from Respondent Inlet Harbour, a South Carolina general partnership,
  to the South Carolina Department of Parks, Recreation and Tourism.Â  The trial
  court held that the implied easement was limited in scope and the Department of
  Parks, Recreation and Tourism appealed.Â  We affirm.
Factual/Procedural
  Background
The
  circumstances giving rise to this case are best explained by way of historical
  narrative.Â  In the early 1970â€™s, a group of investors formed the Inlet Harbour
  general partnership and acquired a large tract of land on the peninsula forming
  the northern border of the entrance to the coastal waterway known as Murrells
  Inlet.Â  The partnership made this acquisition for the purpose of developing
  this area into a residential subdivision.
At
  the time the partnership purchased this land, it was aware that the United
  States Army Corps of Engineers was preparing a substantial engineering project
  to solve navigability problems in the Murrells Inlet waterway.Â  This project,
  referred to as the â€œMurrells Inlet Navigability Project,â€ called for the
  construction of jetties at the north and south entrances to the inlet and for
  routine dredging of the inlet.Â  The project was to be funded with both state
  and federal resources, and the South Carolina Department of Parks, Recreation
  and Tourism (â€œthe Departmentâ€) was charged with acquiring the land necessary
  for the project.Â  The Department was to acquire the necessary property and
  transfer that property to the Corps of Engineers.
The
  land at issue in this case was acquired for the construction and maintenance of
  the jetty at the inletâ€™s north entrance.Â  Inlet Harbour sold a first parcel of
  land to the Department in March 1976.Â  This rather large tract (approximately
  4.2 acres) was located very near the end of the peninsula.Â  The tract bordered
  the ocean on the east and undeveloped property on the west and south.Â  Undeveloped
  residential lots bordered the tract on the north, and Inlet Harbour Drive - the
  yet-to-be-developed thoroughfare through the development - abutted portions of
  the tractâ€™s north and west borders.Â  In addition to describing the property by
  metes and bounds, the deed to the Department referenced a plat recorded roughly
  two weeks earlier.Â  This plat showed the 4.2-acre tract, the adjacent undeveloped
  lots, and the future site of Inlet Harbour Drive.Â  The deed to the Department
  additionally contained an express easement to use Inlet Harbour Drive to access
  the property â€œfor the sole purpose of constructing and maintaining the north
  sand dike and jetty for the Murrells Inlet, South Carolina, Navigation
  Project.â€
Some
  time after this transfer, the Corps of Engineers directed the Department to
  acquire a second tract of land from Inlet Harbour.Â  The Corps required this
  second purchase in the event that it proved necessary to construct a â€œdeflector
  dikeâ€ to maintain the project.Â  The Department believed this second acquisition
  to be unnecessary, but nevertheless acquired this smaller tract of
  approximately 3.56 acres located immediately to the south of the Departmentâ€™s
  larger tract.Â  The parties completed this transaction in July 1977.Â  Like the
  initial land sale, this deed described the conveyed property by reference to a
  plat.Â  Unlike the initial sale, however, this deed did not contain any easement
  over or reference to Inlet Harbour Drive.Â  After this second transaction, the
  Department owned contiguous tracts which comprised the south and southeast
  corners of the north Murrells Inlet peninsula.
The
  Department transferred the 4.2-acre tract of property to the Corps of Engineers
  roughly one month after acquiring the 3.56-acre tract.Â  Because the Department
  felt that the acquisition of the second tract was unnecessary, the Department
  leased the 3.56-acre tract to the Corps instead of transferring title to the
  Corps.Â  Although the transfer of the 4.2-acre tract had the effect of cutting
  the 3.56-acre tract off from road access, it appears that the Corps and the
  Department continued to access the 3.56-acre tract, albeit very infrequently,
  by using Inlet Harbour Drive and then traversing the 4.2-acre tract.Â  The
  Departmentâ€™s lease with the Corps expired in the mid-1990â€™s, and the Corps
  determined that it would not need to construct a deflector dike in order to
  maintain the Navigability Project.Â  The Department then began investigating the
  subdivision and sale of the 3.56-acre tract, and this litigation followed.
The Inlet Harbour partnership initiated this declaratory judgment action against the Department
  requesting that the court declare the scope of the Departmentâ€™s right to use Inlet Harbour Drive to access the 3.56-acre tract.Â  The Department asserted the creation of
  an express easement and an easement implied by necessity as counterclaims, and
  the Department sought to add Respondent Inlet Harbour Property Owners
  Association as a third-party defendant.[1]Â 
  Although the property owners association answered that it had assigned all of
  its rights in this litigation to the partnership, there appears to be no
  continuing dispute involving the property owners associationâ€™s inclusion as a
  party in this case.
The
  trial court entered a grant of partial summary judgment to the Department.Â 
  Relying on the authority of Blue Ridge Realty Company v. Williamson, 247
  S.C. 112, 145 S.E.2d 922 (1965), the trial court held that the Department had
  an easement for ingress and egress over Inlet Harbour Drive which arose out of
  the reference in the Departmentâ€™s deed to a plat depicting subdivided lots and
  streets.Â  Although the trial court held that there was no doubt as to the
  existence of this easement, the court held that there was a genuine issue of
  material fact as to whether the scope of the Departmentâ€™s easement was
  unrestricted or was restricted to purposes relating to the Murrells Inlet
  Navigability Project.Â  The parties proceeded to trial, and at the conclusion of
  the trial, the court held that the Departmentâ€™s easement over Inlet Harbour Drive was limited to environmental purposes associated with maintaining the
  navigability of Murrells Inlet.Â  The Department appealed.
This
  Court certified the appeal from the court of appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b),
  SCACR.Â  The Department raises the following issue for review:

	Did the
  trial court err in holding that the Departmentâ€™s easement to use Inlet Harbour Drive is limited to environmental purposes associated with maintaining the
  navigability of Murrells Inlet?

Standard
  of Review
The
  determination of the existence of an easement is a question of fact in a law
  action, Jowers v. Hornsby, 292 S.C. 549, 551, 357 S.E.2d 710, 711
  (1987), and this Court reviews factual issues relating to the existence of an
  easement under a highly deferential standard.Â  See Townes Associates, Ltd.
    v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 85-86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976)
  (providing that questions of fact in a law action are generally reviewed under
  the â€œany evidenceâ€ standard).Â   
Apart
  from the issue of an easementâ€™s creation, however, the determination of the
  scope of an easement is an action in equity.Â  Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 323, 487 S.E.2d 187, 190 (1997).Â  In an action at equity,
  tried by a judge alone, an appellate court may find facts in accordance with
  its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Townes, 266 S.C. at
  86, 221 S.E.2d at 775.
Law/Analysis
The
  Department argues that the trial court erred in holding that the Departmentâ€™s
  easement over Inlet Harbour Drive is limited to environmental purposes
  associated with maintaining the navigability of Murrells Inlet.Â  We disagree.
An
  easement is a right of use over anotherâ€™s property.Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 457 (5th ed. 1979).Â  Easements can arise
  by both express creation and by implication.Â  Implied easements are based upon
  the theory that whenever one conveys property, he intends to convey whatever is
  necessary for the propertyâ€™s use and enjoyment.Â  17A Am. Jur. Easements Â§ 37 (1957).Â  The purpose of an implied easement is to give effect to the
  intentions of the parties to a transaction, and because the implication of an
  easement in a conveyance goes against the general rule that a written
  instrument speaks for itself, implied easements are not favored.Â  Id.; see also 28A C.J.S. Easements Â§ 61 (1996).
The
  creation of an implied easement generally requires that the facts and
  circumstances surrounding the conveyance, the property, the parties, or some
  other characteristic demonstrate that the objective intention of the parties
  was to create an easement.Â  25 Am. Jur. 2d Easements and Licenses Â§ 19
  (2004); 28A C.J.S. Â§ 62.Â  Courts have, over time, developed various
  presumptions regarding the creation of implied easements in certain circumstances.
  Â One such presumption arises when an owner subdivides his land and has the land
  platted into lots and streets.Â  This Court has recognized the general rule that
  when an owner conveys subdivided lots and references the plat in the deed, the
  owner grants the lot owners an easement over the streets appearing in the
  plat.Â  See, e.g., Blue Ridge Realty Co., 247 S.C. at 118, 145 S.E.2d at
  924-25.[2]
In
  the instant case, the Department argues that the scope of their easement over Inlet Harbour Drive, implied by the Blue Ridge rule, should extend to using Inlet Harbour Drive for residential purposes.Â  The Department first argues that because the
  rule enunciated in Blue Ridge commonly arises when a landowner has
  platted land into a residential subdivision, the rule presumptively creates an
  easement to use the platted roads for residential purposes.Â  The Department
  further argues that the circumstances surrounding this transaction demonstrate
  that the parties did not intend that the 3.56-acre tract be forever limited to environmental
  purposes associated with maintaining the navigability of Murrells Inlet.Â  In
  our view, both arguments miss the mark.
As a
  starting point, we note that the intentions of the parties to the transaction
  are the overriding focus when examining implied easements.Â  McAllister v.
    Smiley, 301 S.C. 10, 16, 389 S.E.2d 857, 862 (1990) (Toal, J. dissenting); 28A
  C.J.S. Â§Â§ 82, 149; 17A Am. Jur. Â§Â§ 40, 116; 25 Am. Jur. 2d Â§ 19.Â  Thus, the
  Department over-reads Blue Ridge considerably in suggesting that
  the case stands for the proposition that an easement created by reference to a
  plat is presumptively an easement of a particular scope.Â  The rule applied in Blue Ridge is nothing more than a presumption that when a grantor conveys property
  with reference to a plat showing streets or other ways of passage, the grantor
  intends to allow the grantee the use of the delineated streets and ways of
  passage.Â  McAllister, 301 S.C. at 11-12, 389 S.E.2d at 858. Â The case Cason
    v. Gibson, 217 S.C. 500, 61 S.E.2d 58 (1950), explained the policy
  underlying this presumption in terms of estoppel.Â  In that case, this Court
  explained that when a grantor conveys land abutting a street, he is estopped
  from denying the streetâ€™s existence and the right of the grantee to its use. Id. at 507, 61 S.E.2d at 61. Â This approach is reasonable, and it is
  also reasonable that when an owner conveys property that has been subdivided
  for residential purposes, the grantor presumably intends for grantees to have
  access to the abutting subdivision streets for normal residential purposes.Â 
  But the property at issue here is not subdivided residential property and abuts
  no road. Â This demonstrates the problems that might occur if we were to apply a
  rigid presumption based solely upon particular geography or land division.Â  Our
  guidepost must be what the parties intended, and the best evidence of the
  partiesâ€™ intentions are the facts and circumstances surrounding the
  conveyance.Â  See McAllister, 301 S.C. 12, 389 S.E.2d at 858-59; 28A
  C.J.S. Â§Â§ 82, 149; 25 Am. Jur. 2d Â§Â§ 19, 21.Â  Thus, to the extent the
  Department urges this Court to ignore everything except the deedâ€™s reference to
  a residential subdivision plat, this argument fails to remain true to the
  principles underlying implied easements.
Our
  analysis accordingly turns to an examination of the facts and circumstances
  surrounding the sale of the 3.56-acre tract.Â  The Department argues that the
  partnership foresaw the likelihood that the 3.56-acre tract could one day be
  developed for residential purposes and that this is evidenced by the fact that both
  the 4.2-acre and the 3.56-acre tracts were carved out of an end of the
  peninsula labeled â€œreserved for future developmentâ€ on one of the partnershipâ€™s
  maps.Â  The Department further argues that this evidence is supported by the
  testimony of a principal of the partnership providing that the partnership
  would have developed this land for residential purposes if it had not sold the
  land to the Department.Â  According to the Department, this evidence supports
  the proposition that the partnership intended for this tract to be used both
  for purposes associated with maintaining the navigability of Murrells Inlet and
  for residential purposes.Â   
We
  believe the trial court wisely discounted these arguments.Â  Relying on testimony
  and evidence in the record, the court below took the view that the Inlet Harbour partnership purchased the land it sought to develop with the express
  understanding that portions of the land on the peninsula would need to be
  conveyed to the government for the specific purpose of the Murrells Inlet
  Navigability Project.Â  This view was supported by testimony from the
  partnership that it engaged in several discussions with the state and federal
  entities involved and that the partnership designed the residential subdivision
  and Inlet Harbour Drive around the land that the project would demand.Â  A
  principal of the partnership further testified that the designation of the
  areas acquired by the Department as â€œreserved for future developmentâ€
  specifically meant that the land was reserved for sale to the Corps of
  Engineers for the project.Â   
A
  clarifying point is instructive.Â  A great deal of the evidence surrounding this
  transaction does not focus directly on the issue of access to these tracts of
  land, but pertains instead to how the parties intended for this land to be
  used.Â  Addressing the question of how this land may be used, the Department
  focuses on the lack of any restrictive covenants in the deed to the 3.56-acre
  tract and argues that it should not be prohibited from developing the property
  where the deed contains no restriction prohibiting such development.Â  But the
  absence of restrictions in the Departmentâ€™s deed is not terribly relevant, and
  it is at this point that we must recognize an important distinction regarding
  what is and what is not at issue in this appeal.Â  The question presented in
  this case is the scope of the Departmentâ€™s right to access the 3.56-acre tract
  through a specific route, not a limitation of the Departmentâ€™s right to use
  that tract.Â  The Department unquestionably has the same right to make use of
  its land as does any landowner. Â The concepts of deed warranties and
  restrictive covenants are thus largely irrelevant in this case.
This
  does not mean, however, that we should disregard the evidence of how the
  parties intended these tracts to be used as irrelevant to the issue of how the
  parties intended to treat access to these tracts. Â We do not think that the subjects
  can be completely separated.Â  If the partnership designed its subdivision
  around the land that it knew the government would require and intended for this
  land to only be used for purposes related to the Murrells Inlet Navigability
  Project, that supports the proposition that the partnership intended for Inlet
  Harbour Drive to provide only a limited right of access to these tracts.Â  Stated
  differently, the fact that the partnership contemplated a specific and limited
  use of this property is evidence that the partnership contemplated a specific
  and limited use of Inlet Harbour Drive to access the property.Â  That this
  limited right of access would be the only right of access over Inlet Harbour
  Drive is further supported by the fact that the partnership initially attempted
  to insert a clause in the deed to the 4.2-acre tract that would have caused
  ownership of the tract to revert to the partnership if the property ceased to
  be used for the jetty project.Â  The Department advised that a reverter would
  not comply with its responsibility under the project to acquire full title, and
  the parties thus crafted the express but limited easement found in the deed to
  the 4.2-acre tract.Â  Â 
The
  Department does not point us to any evidence demonstrating that the parties contemplated
  a broader use of Inlet Harbour Drive or intended for this land to one day be
  used for purposes unrelated to the Murrells Inlet Navigability Project.Â  Indeed,
  the Department did not even offer testimony that it contemplated residential development
  of the 3.56-acre tract at the time of purchase. Â While we can say that the
  Department is correct in that its failure to secure utility easements or an
  easement across the 4.2-acre tract does not conclusively prove that later
  development was not contemplated at the time the partnership sold the 3.56-acre
  tract to the Department, the acquisition of such easements would make the
  Departmentâ€™s claim considerably stronger.[3]Â 
  The Department could have similarly bolstered its case through bargaining
  expressly for an unrestricted easement over Inlet Harbour Drive at the time it
  purchased the 3.56-acre tract from the partnership.Â  Having not done so, the
  Court is left to discern how the parties intended to treat access to this
  property.Â  Under these circumstances, we cannot say that the trial court erred
  in considering the failure to bargain for express utility and access easements
  in an effort to ascertain the partiesâ€™ intentions.
The
  Departmentâ€™s strongest argument for reversal is one based largely on equity.Â 
  The argument goes that because Inlet Harbour subdivision is a residential
  subdivision, there is no additional servitude imposed on Inlet Harbour Drive by
  allowing the Department to use the road for residential purposes.Â  The
  Department bolsters this argument with the assertion that due to the propertyâ€™s
  oceanfront location, the propertyâ€™s value will be quite large if road access is
  granted and quite small if road access is denied.Â  The Department argues that
  the fact that it leased the land to the Corps of Engineers instead of selling
  the land evidences the Departmentâ€™s intention to sell the property if it was
  not needed for the project.
But
  the equities in this case do not cut solely in the Departmentâ€™s favor.Â  Absent
  an easement or a license, a landowner generally enjoys no right to use the land
  of another.Â  Implied easements ask the court to take a deed between grantor and
  grantee which is silent regarding any grant or reservation of a right to cross
  one partyâ€™s land to access the otherâ€™s and imply what the parties must have
  meant to include in the deed but did not.Â  In this case, this Court is charged
  with determining what the partnership and the Department meant to include in
  the deed regarding the Departmentâ€™s ability to use Inlet Harbour Drive to
  access the 3.56-acre tract. Â We find that there is simply very little support
  for the proposition that the circumstances surrounding this transaction
  evidence any intent by the parties that an easement over Inlet Harbour Drive
  extend beyond uses relating to the Murrells Inlet Navigability Project.Â  The
  trial court viewed the evidence and determined that the parties intended for
  the limited access appearing in the deed to the 4.2-acre tract to serve both
  parcels, and we agree with the trial courtâ€™s determination.
Two
  final points are instructive.Â  First, although the Departmentâ€™s argument about
  retaining the 3.56-acre tract instead of transferring the tract to the Corps of
  Engineers is arguably evidence that the Department contemplated someday selling
  the 3.56-acre property at the time it conveyed the 4.2-acre tract to the Corps,
  there is no evidence that Inlet Harbour partnership participated in this
  decision or was even aware of it.Â  Similarly, the Departmentâ€™s argument based
  on having paid fair market value for the 3.56-acre tract is unpersuasive.Â  The
  Department paid fair market value for the 4.2-acre tract despite the grant of a
  limited easement to access that tract, and the record contains testimony that
  the Department was statutorily required to purchase these tracts for fair
  market value.
In
  sum, we hold that the trial court properly concluded that the parties to this
  transaction did not intend for this land to be accessed by Inlet Harbour Drive
  for purposes unrelated to the Murrells Inlet Navigability Project.Â 
  Accordingly, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision that the Department of Parks,
  Recreation and Tourismâ€™s easement over Inlet Harbour Drive is limited to
  environmental purposes associated with maintaining the navigability of Murrells
  Inlet.[4]
Conclusion
For
  the foregoing reasons, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision.
MOORE, WALLER,
  JJ., and Acting Justice James W. Johnson, Jr., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J.,
  dissenting in a separate opinion.
JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent, and would hold the circuit
  court erred in limiting the scope of the Department of Parks, Recreation and
  Tourismâ€™s (PRTâ€™s) easement over Inlet Harbour Drive.
The circuit courtâ€™s
  finding of an implied easement has not been appealed and is therefore the law
  of the case.Â  E.g. Dreher v. Dreher, 370 S.C. 75, 634 S.E.2d 646
  (2006).Â  The sole issue is whether the court erred in limiting the PRTâ€™s road
  easement as it relates to the second tract it purchased from respondent to
  â€œenvironmental purposes associated with maintaining the navigability of
  Murrells Inlet.â€Â  The majority and I agree on the applicable legal principles,
  but I draw a different conclusion about the partiesâ€™ intentions after examining
  the facts and circumstances surrounding the conveyance of the 3.56 acre tract.
 
In
  1976, PRT bought a 4.2 acre tract from respondent at the behest of the Army
  Corps of Engineers.Â  This 1976 deed contained an express easement limiting
  PRTâ€™s right to ingress and egress over Inlet Harbour Drive to â€œthe sole purpose
  of constructing and maintaining the north sand dike and jetty for the Murrells
  Inlet, South Carolina, Navigation Project.â€Â  More than a year later, PRT
  purchased the 3.56 tract at the insistence of the Corps.Â  Among the facts and
  circumstances surrounding this second transaction was PRTâ€™s belief, ultimately
  vindicated, that this tract would not be necessary for the Corpsâ€™ Murrells
  Inlet project.Â  Accordingly, there was a need to preserve this tractâ€™s
  commercial viability.Â  Even more critically in my opinion, the 1977 deed to the
  3.56 acres contains no express easement, much less one limiting PRTâ€™s access to
  Inlet Harbour Drive, as had the March 1976 deed to the 4.2 acre tract.Â  As I
  view the facts and circumstances surrounding the second conveyance, I can draw
  only one conclusion:Â  that the parties did not intend any restriction upon the
  scope of PRTâ€™s Inlet Harbour Drive easement as it relates to the 3.56 acre
  tract.
Accordingly, I
  would reverse.

[1] In the interim period between the Departmentâ€™s transfer of the 4.2-acre tract
  to the Corps and the expiration of the lease, the Inlet Harbour partnership
  transferred ownership of Inlet Harbour Drive to the Inlet Harbour Property
  Owners Association.
[2] Other examples of these presumptions are easements implied where the grantor used
  one portion of property to serve another prior to severance (easements implied
  by prior use), and easements implied where an easement is necessary to allow a
  grantee to have meaningful access to his land (easements implied by
  necessity).Â  See Boyd v. Bell South Tel. Tel. Co., Inc., 369 S.C. 410,
  633 S.E.2d 136 (2006) (extensively discussing implied easements).
[3] The Department eventually acquired an easement across the 4.2-acre tract, but
  that acquisition did not occur until 1996.Â   
[4] We note that access to the property over navigable water has not been addressed
  at any point in this case.Â  We therefore assume that the property is accessible
  over navigable water.Â  See 25 Am. Jur. 2d Â§ 38 (providing that an
  easement by necessity will generally not be implied where property is
  accessible by navigable water); 28A C.J.S. Â§ 98 (same). Â

title: Englert, Inc. v. LeafGuard USA, Inc.
description: The issue here is whether summary judgment was properly granted to respondent, Englert.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Englert, Inc., Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				LeafGuard USA,
      Inc., Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF 
CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Horry County
Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 26460
Heard February 5, 2008 - Filed March 24,
  2008Â Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				John W.
  Fletcher, of Barnwell Whaley Patterson & Helms, of Charleston, for
  Petitioner.
				Mark
  McAdams, and Amanda A. Bailey, of McNair Law Firm PA, of Myrtle Beach, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  WALLER: Â We granted certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion in Englert,
    Inc. v. LeafGuard USA, Inc., 365 S.C. 565, 619 S.E.2d 12 (Ct. App. 2005).Â 
  The Court of Appeals affirmed the partial grant of summary judgment to
  Respondent, Englert, Inc., finding Englert was entitled to possession of a
  gutter-fabricating machine which was in the possession of Petitioner, LeafGuard
  USA, Inc.Â  We reverse the grant of summary judgment.
FACTS
Jerry
  Dan Vickory is the owner of two companies which manufacture and install
  gutters: LeafGuard USA and Seamless Gutters of Socastee.Â  In 1993, Vickory, on
  behalf of Seamless Gutters, entered into a Sub-License Agreement with Englert,
  Inc., a distributor of seamless gutter machines and raw materials used in
  manufacturing seamless gutters.Â  Pursuant to the agreement, Seamless Gutters
  was granted the right to manufacture, sell, and install Englertâ€™s product, the
  LeafGuard Gutter System, in a set sales territory.Â  The agreement set forth
  minimum sales quotas and required Seamless Gutters to pay Englert royalties.Â  The
  agreement required Seamless Gutters to purchase a $26,000 gutter-fabricating
  machine to produce the Englert Gutter System.Â Â  The contract includes the
  following buy-back provision:

	Upon termination of this Agreement, Englert shall purchase, and
  Sub-Licensee shall sell, the Englert LeafGuard Gutter Machine, subject to
  normal wear and tear and pay Sub-Licensee at a price equal to the greater of:
	(i) the depreciated value of the Englert LeafGuard Gutter Machine,
  based on a depreciated rate of 20% per year on the original price; or
	(ii) $1.00

In 1998, LeafGuard USA entered into a SubLicense Agreement with
  Englert which was substantially similar to the 1993 agreement between Englert
  and Seamless Gutters.Â  As with the prior agreement, LeafGuard USA had minimum sales quotas (15,000 feet of gutters per year), and was required to pay
  royalties.Â  Although the 1998 contract required LeafGuard USA to purchase an Englert LeafGuard Gutter Machine for $28,000.00, it is undisputed that
  LeafGuard USA simply took possession of and utilized the LeafGuard Gutter
  Machine purchased by Seamless Gutters in 1993.Â   
The
  1998 agreement contains the same buy-back provision, allowing Englert to repurchase
  the LeafGuard Gutter Machine for $1.00 after full depreciation.Â  The 1998
  agreement was for an initial two year term from Jan. 1, 1999- Dec. 31, 2000 and
  provided that it would continue for additional one year periods thereafter, â€œif
  Licensee has materially complied with all of the provisions of this License.â€Â 
  However, the agreement provided that if the licensee breached any provision or
  remained in default for a period of thirty days after written notice from
  Englert (or 10 days written notice in the event of failure to pay royalties),
  Englert had the right to cancel the agreement and terminate the license
  immediately.Â   
On
  March 15, 2001, Englert sent LeafGuard USA a letter advising that after
  numerous attempts at trying to contact LeafGuard USA, it was terminating the Sub-Licensing
  Agreement for the following reasons:

	-Â Â Failure to meet the established sales target amount
  agreed as stated in the Sub-License Agreement under section 5C.
	-Â Â As stated in the Sub-License Agreement under Section 6E,
  should Sub-Licensee be in default on its payment obligations to Englert for 60
  days, Englert may, at its option, terminate this License Agreement and/or seek
  any other options open to Englert, taking over the repossessing SubLicenseeâ€™s
  Englert LeafGuard Gutter Machine and/or rescinding Sub-Licensee from further
  manufacturing and distributing of Englert LeafGuard, and initiating the
  collection of the amounts owed to Englert.

The letter went
  on to advise that LeafGuard USA was 11,060 feet short of its 2000 sales quota,
  and that it was over 60 days past due in payment of royalties.Â  Thereafter,
  Englert advised LeafGuard USA that it was to terminate all use of Englertâ€™s
  trademarks, and was to make arrangements for the immediate return of the gutter
  machine, at its expense, for which it would be paid $1.00 for the machine, in
  accordance with the licensing agreement.Â Â   
LeafGuard
  USA did not return the machine and on July 30, 2001, Englert filed a Claim
  and Delivery action.Â  One year later, on June 17, 2002, Judge Breeden denied
  Englertâ€™s motion for immediate possession of the gutter machine.Â  Englert filed
  an amended complaint in March 2003 seeking an injunction and other relief.Â 
  LeafGuard USA answered and alleged the affirmative defenses of waiver,
  estoppel, laches, unclean hands, fraud and bad faith (among other defenses).Â 
  LeafGuard USA also filed a counterclaim, alleging unfair and deceptive trade
  practices, breach of contract, breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent
  act, and fraud.Â   
After a
  hearing, Judge Harwell granted Englertâ€™s motion for partial summary judgment,
  essentially holding that since the partiesâ€™ contract was terminated, Englert
  had an absolute right to repossess the machine.Â  Judge Harwell also found that
  LeafGuard USAâ€™s counterclaims did not preclude summary judgment.Â  The Court of
  Appeals affirmed.Â  Englert, Inc. v. LeafGuard USA, Inc., 365 S.C. 565,
  619 S.E.2d 12 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  The Court of Appeals addressed only LeafGuard
  USAâ€™s primary issue, in which it asserted summary judgment could not be granted
  to Englert because the machine had actually been sold to Seamless Gutters, such
  that the court could not order a transfer of ownership from a non-party.Â  The
  Court of Appeals ruled that the two companies were in reality the same company,
  such that the grant of summary judgment was proper.Â  The Court of Appeals did
  not address whether LeafGuard USAâ€™s counterclaims and affirmative defenses were
  sufficient to raise a genuine issue of material fact.
ISSUE

	Did the trial court err in granting summary judgment where
  LeafGuard USAâ€™s defenses and counterclaims had not been ruled on?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
When
  reviewing a grant of summary judgment, the appellate court applies the same
  standard applied by the trial court pursuant to Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Hansson
    v. Scalise Builders of South Carolina, 374 S.C. 352, 650 S.E.2d 658 (2007); David v. McLeod Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 367 S.C. 242, 247, 626 S.E.2d 1, 3
  (2006).Â  Summary judgment is appropriate when â€œthe pleadings, depositions,
  answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the
  affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact
  and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule
  56(c), SCRCP.Â  When determining if any triable issues of fact exist, the
  evidence and all reasonable inferences must be viewed in the light most
  favorable to the non-moving party. David, 367 S.C. at 247, 626 S.E.2d at
  3.Â  Moreover, since it is a drastic remedy, summary judgment should be
  cautiously invoked so that a litigant will not be improperly deprived of a trial
  on disputed factual issues.Â  Connor v. City of Forest Acres, 348 S.C.
  454, 560 S.E.2d 606 (2002).Â  â€œThe purpose of summary judgment is to expedite
  the disposition of cases which do not require the services of a fact finder.â€ George
    v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001). Summary judgment
  is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts of the case is
  desirable to clarify the application of the law.Â  Baugus v. Wessinger, 303
  S.C. 412, 401 S.E.2d 169 (1991).
DISCUSSION
LeafGuard
  USA contends there are genuine issues of material fact as to whether the
  contract was properly terminated by Englert, thereby precluding the entry of
  summary judgment.Â  We agree.Â   
LeafGuard
  USA submitted the affidavit of its owner, Jerry Vickory, in opposition to
  Englertâ€™s motion for summary judgment.[1]Â 
  In the affidavit, Vickory contends Englert was upset with LeafGuard USA for having developed its own website to market LeafGuard products, and that for complaining
  about Englert infringing on its LeafGuard USA trademark.Â  Vickoryâ€™s affidavit
  asserts that Englert representatives told him, and his wife, that they would
  â€œget us and take away our franchise.â€Â  Vickory also contends that prior to
  Englertâ€™s discovery of the website, he had heard nothing about failing to meet
  sales quotas or unpaid royalties and had, in fact, been recently commended on
  his sales.[2]Â 
  Vickory asserted that throughout his course of dealing with Englert, if there
  was ever any issue as to minimum footage in a given year, LeafGuard USA was permitted to purchase extra rolls to make up the difference.Â 
 
We find
  the information contained in Vickoryâ€™s affidavit, along with its counterclaims,
  and affirmative defenses, are sufficient to create genuine issues of material
  fact as to whether or not Englert properly terminated the contract.Â 
  Accordingly, under the facts presented, we find the trial court erred in
  granting summary judgment in favor of Englert.Â  The Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion
  affirming the grant of summary judgment is
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  MOORE, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice J. Michelle Childs, concur.

[1] Â Englert asserts the affidavit was untimely, as
  it was not filed until after the hearing on the motion for summary judgment.Â 
  However, it is undisputed that the affidavit was filed prior to the trial
  courtâ€™s ruling, and there being no indication in the record that the trial
  court did not consider the affidavit, we must assume it was considered.Â  Cf. Smith v. Hastie, 367 S.C. 410, 626 S.E.2d 13 (Ct. App. 2005)
  (recognizing that it is within a trial judgeâ€™s discretion to accept late
  affidavits in opposition to a motion for summary judgment).Â   
[2]Â  In fact, a letter dated Dec. 15,
  2000, from Englert to LeafGuard USA states â€œGood job.Â  Keep selling.â€Â

title: Brenco v. South Carolina Department of Transportation
description: The Court reversed the Court of Appeals, holding that the master did not abuse his discretion when he refused to reopen the case for additional testimony.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Brenco, a
      General Partnership, Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				South Carolina
      Department of Transportation, Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal From Horry County
Â J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Master-in-Equity
Opinion No. 26461
Heard February 5, 2008 - Filed March 24,
  2008Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			John B. McCutcheon, Jr., Mary Ruth M. Baxter, and Arrigo P.
  Carotti, all of McCutcheon, McCutcheon & Baxter, of Conway, for Petitioner.
			Howell V. Bellamy, Jr., and Douglas M. Zayicek, both of Bellamy,
  Rutenberg, Copeland, Epps, Gravely & Bowers, PA, of Myrtle Beach, for
  Respondent.
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Brenco (respondent) brought suit against the Department
  of Transportation (petitioner) relating to a deed for the sale of a portion of
  its property along Highway 501 in Horry County, as well as for inverse
  condemnation.Â  The master-in-equity found in favor of petitioner with respect
  to respondentâ€™s causes of action for rescission of the deed due to mutual
  mistake, rescission due to unilateral mistake, negligent misrepresentation, and
  declaratory judgment.Â  The master took respondentâ€™s inverse condemnation claim
  under advisement but later ruled in favor of petitioner.Â   
The Court of
  Appeals affirmed the masterâ€™s ruling on the causes of action related to the
  deed but reversed the masterâ€™s decision not to reopen the case and remanded for
  additional testimony as to damages stemming from inverse condemnation.Â  Brenco
    v. S.C. Dept. of Transp., 363 S.C. 136, 609 S.E.2d 531 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  We
  granted petitionerâ€™s request for certiorari review and now reverse.
FACTS
Respondent
  owns property located along Highway 501 in Horry County.Â  The property formerly
  served as the location of a Brendleâ€™s store.Â  In 1998, respondent sold to
  petitioner, in lieu of condemnation, a small portion of respondentâ€™s parking
  lot in order to build a frontage road as part of an ongoing plan to renovate
  and widen Highway 501.Â  The negotiations before execution of the deed and the deed
  itself referenced aspects of petitionerâ€™s 1993 plans for the Highway 501
  project. Â As a result of this conveyance, respondent lost direct access to
  Highway 501 but retained ingress and egress to the frontage road.
The final project
  was completed pursuant to updated plans drafted by petitioner in 2000- not the
  1993 plans referenced in the deed.Â  As part of the change in plans, petitioner also
  elevated Highway 501 twenty-five feet[1] and reconfigured exit ramps in close proximity to respondentâ€™s property in both
  the eastbound and westbound directions on Highway 501.Â   
At trial, the main
  thrust of respondentâ€™s case centered on its cause of action for rescission of
  the deed.Â  Specifically, respondent alleged petitioner had not been forthcoming
  during negotiations, and respondent claimed it did not know it would lose
  direct access to Highway 501.Â  Respondent also argued that petitioner knew the
  grade of Highway 501 would eventually be elevated but did not disclose that
  information to respondent before delivery of the deed.Â  Respondentâ€™s witnesses who
  testified as to damages focused on a comparison of the values of the entire
  property before the 1998 conveyance and the property after Highway 501 was
  completed pursuant to the 2000 plans.Â   
After ruling on the
  deed issues, the master advised the parties he was struggling with the issue of
  damages relating to the inverse condemnation claim.Â  Respondent thereafter
  moved to reopen the case for the taking of additional testimony as to potential
  damages stemming from inverse condemnation.Â  The master denied respondentâ€™s
  motion to reopen the case and found in favor of petitioner on the inverse
  condemnation cause of action.Â   
ISSUE
Did
  the Court of Appeals err in finding the master-in-equity abused his discretion
  by refusing to reopen the case for additional evidence regarding respondentâ€™s
  purported damages due to inverse condemnation?
ANALYSIS
The
  decision whether to reopen a record for additional evidence is within the trial
  courtâ€™s sound discretion and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of
  that discretion.Â  Wright v. Strickland, 306 S.C. 187, 188, 410 S.E.2d
  596, 597 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  The trial judge is endowed with considerable
  latitude and discretion in allowing a party to reopen a case.Â  Spinx Oil
    Co., Inc. v. Fed. Mut. Ins. Co., 310 S.C. 477, 482, 427 S.E.2d 649, 651
  (1993), overruled on other grounds, Joe Harden Builders, Inc. v. Aetna Cas. and Sur. Co., 326 S.C. 231, 486 S.E.2d 89 (1997). 
 
The Court of
  Appeals relied on Wright in reversing the master.Â  In Wright, the
  Court of Appeals affirmed a trial judgeâ€™s refusal to reopen the record where
  the moving party did not proffer any testimony or show that the evidence could
  make any difference to the outcome of the case.Â  Wright, 306 S.C. at 188,
  410 S.E.2d at 597.Â  The Court of Appeals distinguished Wright from the
  instant case by noting that respondent attempted to proffer testimony[2] and that the additional testimony would have helped the master.Â  
 
The Court of Appeals also considered
  that respondent did not learn it needed to establish damages in a different
  fashion, i.e. apart from damages calculated for the deed claims, until after
  the masterâ€™s ruling on the deed issues.
We disagree with the
  Court of Appealsâ€™ reasoning.Â  First, respondent was well aware before trial
  that petitioner took the position that respondent could not prove damages stemming
  from the elevation of Highway 501 and the road reconfiguration.Â  Petitioner maintained
  this view throughout trial and provided expert testimony on the precise issue.Â 
  Respondent had ample opportunity to present testimony and evidence regarding
  inverse condemnation damages at trial, but it instead decided to present
  evidence of damages as if the deed would be rescinded and the property would be
  valued as it existed prior to any condemnation proceeding.Â  The master did not
  abuse his discretion by refusing to allow respondent a second opportunity to
  present its inverse condemnation case after it failed on its other claims.Â  See Owens v. S.C. State Hwy. Dept., 239 S.C. 44, 54, 121 S.E.2d 240, 245
  (1961) (landowner has the burden of proving its damages for a taking of its
  property, whether through condemnation proceedings or inverse condemnation).
The Court of
  Appealsâ€™ citation of Wright in its reversal of the master may be read to
  imply that a trial judge may abuse his discretion by refusing to reopen the
  record simply because additional testimony is proffered and would make any difference to the outcome of the case.Â  This is not the proper standard for
  reviewing a potential abuse of discretion in regard to post-trial motions to
  reopen a record.Â  See Spinx, supra (no abuse of discretion
  in declining to reopen the record when party could have provided same evidence
  at trial).Â  Accordingly, the Court of Appeals erred in remanding the case to
  the master for the taking of additional testimony.[3]
CONCLUSION
Notwithstanding
  that after Hardin no inverse condemnation taking has occurred, we hold
  that the master did not abuse his discretion in refusing to reopen the case.Â 
  The Court of Appeals opinion is  
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice J. Michelle Childs, concur.

[1] Previously, Highway 501 was twenty-two feet above sea
  level.Â  The grade elevation brought the highway to a total height of
  forty-seven feet above sea level.Â   
[2] Respondent offered to proffer testimony at the
  hearing that addressed respondentâ€™s motion for reconsideration of the order
  disposing of the inverse condemnation claim.
[3] Furthermore, in light of our decision in Hardin v.
  S.C. Dept. of Transp., 371 S.C. 598, 641 S.E.2d 437 (2007), petitionerâ€™s
  actions in this case were not a taking by inverse condemnation.
