title: Foothills Brewing Concern v. City of Greenville
description: In this direct appeal, the Court decides the issue of the validity of a local ordinance which bans smoking in bars and restaurants.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The Foothills
      Brewing Concern, Inc., 4MB, Inc., Greenville Wings, Inc., Addy's, Inc., City
      Tavern, Inc., Greenville 0036, LLC, Euphoria, LLC, WTK, Inc., Drumcliff
      Abbey, Inc., and Club Management, LLC, Respondents
				v.
				The City of Greenville, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26467
Heard January 9, 2008 - Filed March 31,
2008Â Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Ronald
  W. McKinney, of Greenville, for Appellant.
				Randall
  Scott Hiller, of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE WALLER: In this direct appeal, the trial
  court ruled that a municipal ordinance banning smoking in bars and restaurants
is preempted by State law and violates the State Constitution.Â  The City of Greenville (the City) appeals from the trial courtâ€™s order.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
In 1987, the City was the first
  municipality in South Carolina to pass an ordinance regulating smoking in
  public places.Â  The 1987 ordinance applied to such areas as government-owned
  buildings, theaters, and office buildings.Â  However, the 1987 ordinance
exempted bars, and for restaurants, it authorized designated smoking areas.
In 1990, the Legislature enacted the Clean
  Indoor Air Act of 1990.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-95-10 et seq. (2002).Â  The Clean Indoor Air Act provides that it is â€œunlawful for a person to smoke or possess lighted smoking
  material in any formâ€ in various public indoor areas such as: Â (1) public
  schools; (2) daycare centers; (3) health care facilities; (4) government
  buildings; (5) elevators; (6) public transportation vehicles; and (7) public
  performing art centers.Â  See Â§ 44-95-20.[1]Â 
  A violation of the Clean Indoor Air Act
  constitutes a misdemeanor, and upon conviction, the violator â€œmust be fined not
less than ten dollars nor more than twenty-five dollars.â€Â  Â§ 44-95-50.
Because of the reported dangers of
  second-hand smoke, the City sought to more comprehensively regulate smoking in
  public places. Therefore, on October 30, 2006, the City enacted Ordinance No.
  2006-91 (the Ordinance).Â  In the â€œFindings and Determinationsâ€ section of the Ordinance,
the City stated as follows:
Numerous studies have found that tobacco
  smoke is a major contributor to indoor air pollution, and that breathing second
  hand smoke â€¦ is a cause of disease in healthy nonsmokers, including heart
disease, stroke, respiratory disease, and lung cancerâ€¦.
The City recognizes that smoke creates a
  danger to the health and safety of the public at large and that, in order to
  protect the health and welfare of the public, it is necessary to restrict
smoking in the manner provided for in this ordnance.
The Ordinance prohibits smoking in: Â (1) all
  enclosed public places, including bars and restaurants; (2) places of
employment; and (3) certain outdoor areas, such as stadiums and zoos.Â   
The section of the Ordinance governing violations and
penalties states as follows, in pertinent part:

	
		
			A.
			A person who smokes in an area 
			where smoking is prohibited by the provisions of this Ordinance 
			shall be guilty
of an infraction, punishable by a fine â€¦.
 
		
		
			B.  
			A person who owns, manages, 
			operates, or otherwise controls a public place or place of 
			employment and who fails to comply with the provisions of this 
			Ordinance shall be guilty of an
infraction, punishable by [a fine].
 
		
		
			â€¦
 
			 
		
		
			D. 
			Violation of this Ordinance is 
			hereby declared to be a public nuisance.
		
	

(Emphasis added).
Respondents all own and operate restaurants and/or bars
  in the City.Â  In December 2006, respondents filed a declaratory judgment action
  contending the Ordinance was invalid and seeking injunctive relief.Â  The trial
  court denied respondentsâ€™ requests for a temporary restraining order and a
  preliminary injunction.Â  The Ordinance went into effect at noon on January 1,
  2007.Â  On March 8, 2007, however, the trial court issued an order declaring the
  Ordinance was both unconstitutional and preempted by State law.Â  Consequently,
the trial court permanently enjoined the City from enforcing the Ordinance.Â 
 
ISSUE

	Did the trial court err in ruling that the
  Ordinance is preempted by State law and violates the South Carolina
Constitution?Â  

DISCUSSION
The City argues the Ordinance is not
  preempted by State law and is consistent
with both the Constitution and the general law of the State.Â  We agree.
A two-step process is used to determine whether a
  local ordinance is valid. Â Denene, Inc. v. City of
    Charleston, 352 S.C. 208, 212, 574 S.E.2d 196, 198 (2002); Bugsyâ€™s
      v. City of Myrtle Beach, 340 S.C. 87, 93, 530 S.E.2d 890, 893
  (2000).Â  First, the Court must consider whether the municipality had the power
  to enact the ordinance.Â  If the State has preempted a particular area of
  legislation, a municipality lacks power to regulate the field, and the ordinance
  is invalid.Â  Id.Â  If, however, the municipality had the power to enact
  the ordinance, the Court must then determine whether the ordinance is
  consistent with the Constitution and the general law of the State.Â  Id.
To preempt an entire field, â€œan act must make manifest
  a legislative intent that no other enactment may touch upon the subject in any
  way.â€Â  Bugsyâ€™s, 340 S.C. at 94, 530 S.E.2d at 893 (citing Town
    of Hilton Head Island v. Fine Liquors, Ltd., 302 S.C. 550, 397 S.E.2d 662
  (1990)).Â  Furthermore, â€œfor there to be a conflict between a state statute and
  a municipal ordinance â€˜both must contain either express or implied conditions
  which are inconsistent or irreconcilable with each otherâ€¦. Â If either is silent
  where the other speaks, there can be no conflict between them.Â  Where no
  conflict exists, both laws stand.â€™â€Â  Town of Hilton Head Island v. Fine
    Liquors, Ltd., 302 S.C. at 553, 397 S.E.2d at 664 (quoting McAbee
v. Southern Rwy., Co., 166 S.C. 166, 169-70, 164 S.E. 444, 445 (1932)). Â 
In the instant case, the trial court found
  that a 1996 legislative act - Act 445 -
expressly preempts the Ordinance.Â  We find no preemption.
Act 445 accomplished two separate objectives:Â  (1) it amended section 44-95-20 of the Clean Indoor Air Act;[2] and (2) it amended and added statutes
  related to the distribution of tobacco products to minors.Â  See S.C.
Code Ann. Â§Â§ 16-17-500 thru -504 (2003).Â   
Section 16-17-500 is a criminal statute
  which makes it a misdemeanor for anyone to sell or give a tobacco product to a
  minor. Â Section 3 of Act 445 amended this section by revising the penalties for
  the offense. Â Section 2 of Act 445 added sections 16-17-501, 16-17-502, 16-17-503,
  and 16-17-504 to the Code.Â  Section 16-17-501 provides definitions relating to the
  distribution of tobacco products; section 16-17-502 makes it unlawful to
  distribute a tobacco sample to a minor; and section 16-17-503 provides for
enforcement and federal reporting.
Section 16-17-504, entitled â€œImplementation; local
laws,â€ provides as follows:

	(A)
  Sections 16-17-500, 16-17-502, and 16-17-503 must be implemented in an
  equitable and uniform manner throughout the State and enforced to ensure the
  eligibility for and receipt of federal funds or grants the State receives or
  may receive relating to the sections.Â  Any laws, ordinances, or rules
    enacted pertaining to tobacco products may not supersede state law or
    regulation.Â  Nothing herein shall affect the right of any person having
  ownership or otherwise controlling private property to allow or prohibit the use
of tobacco products on such property.
	(B) Smoking
  ordinances in effect before the effective date of this act are exempt from the
requirements of subsection (A).

Â§ 16-17-504 (emphasis added).
The trial court found that the second
  sentence of section 16-17-504(A) (emphasized above) applies not only to the statutory
  sections regarding the furnishing of tobacco to minors, but also applies to the
  Clean Indoor Air Act.Â  The trial court therefore determined that this portion
  of section 16-17-504(A) expressly preempts local ordinances such as the
  Ordinance passed by the City in 2006.Â  The trial court concluded that by
  â€œincluding the second sentence in section 16-17-504(A), the General Assembly
  intended to prohibit local government from imposing any restriction on indoor
smoking beyond the restrictions contained in the Clean Indoor Air Act.â€Â   
The City contends that the sections of Act
  445 dealing with the distribution of tobacco products to minors were intended
  to address prerequisites set by the federal government in order to be eligible
  for certain grant funds.Â  See, e.g., Â§ 16-17-503 (specifically
  referencing compliance with the federal Public Health Service Act, 42 U.S.C. Â§
  300x-26).Â  Because of the limited focus and purpose of these statutes, the City
  argues the trial court erred by essentially exporting a portion of section
16-17-504 over to the Clean Indoor Air Act.Â  We agree with the City.
The primary rule of statutory construction is to
  ascertain and effectuate the intent of the Legislature.Â  E.g., Hodges
    v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000).Â  When
  construing statutory language, the statute must be read as a whole, and
  sections which are part of the same general statutory law must be construed
  together and each one given effect.Â  Denene, 352 S.C. at 212, 574 S.E.2d
  at198; TNS Mills, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 331 S.C. 611,
  503 S.E.2d 471 (1998).Â  Moreover, â€œ[a] statute should not be construed by
  concentrating on an isolated phrase.â€Â  South Carolina State Ports Auth. v. Jasper County, 368 S.C. 388, 398, 629 S.E.2d 624, 629 (2006).Â  Finally, the Court
  must presume the Legislature did not intend a futile act, but rather intended
its statutes to accomplish something.Â  Denene, supra.
We find the trial court erred when it isolated a
  phrase from section 16-17-504 and interpreted it in such a way as to accomplish
  preemption under the Clean Indoor Air Act.Â  See South Carolina State Ports Auth., supra (statute should not be construed by concentrating on an isolated
  phrase).Â  While sections which are part of the same general
  statutory law must be construed together and each one given effect, see Denene, supra, this is easily accomplished by looking at the plain language in
  section 16-17-504 and applying it only to sections 16-17-500, 16-17-502, and
  16-17-503.Â  To apply section 16-17-504 more broadly than that would effectively
  change the meaning of an unambiguous statute, which we refuse to do.Â  See Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. at 85, 533 S.E.2d at 581 (â€œUnder the plain meaning rule, it is not the courtâ€™s place
to change the meaning of a clear and unambiguous statute.â€).
In other words, it is patent that the language
  regarding â€œordinancesâ€ found in section 16-17-504 is intended to relate
  specifically to the distribution of â€œtobacco productsâ€ to minors, and not to the
  regulation of indoor smoking.Â  Hodges v. Rainey, supra (the cardinal
  rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the
  Legislature).Â  Merely because section 16-17-504 was added to the Code in the
  same piece of legislation which amended the Clean Indoor Air Act does not
  require that this sectionâ€™s language about local laws be interpreted as part of
the Clean Indoor Air Act.Â   
Accordingly, the trial court erred in deciding that
Act 445 expressly preempts the Ordinance.
Moreover, we note the Clean Indoor Air Act did not
  preempt the entire field of indoor smoking.Â  There simply is no expressly stated intent in the statute that the State chose to exclusively regulate the
  subject of indoor smoking.Â  See Bugsyâ€™s, 340 S.C. at 94, 530
  S.E.2d at 893 (to accomplish field preemption, â€œan act must make manifest
  a legislative intent that no other enactment may touch upon the subject in any
wayâ€).[3]Â   
Because Act 445 and the Clean Indoor Air Act itself do
  not preempt the City from legislating in this area, we find the City had the
  power to enact the Ordinance.Â  Thus, the Ordinance survives step one of the
  analysis.Â  See Denene, supra; Bugsyâ€™s, supra.Â 
  Next, under step two, we must determine whether the Ordinance is consistent
with the Constitution and the general law of the State.Â  Id.
The trial court found the Ordinance violated Article
  VIII, section 14 of the South Carolina Constitution.Â  Specifically, the trial court stated that because a violation of the
  Clean Indoor Air Act constitutes a misdemeanor punishable by a fine, and the
  Ordinance provides for a fine for smoking in areas not prohibited by the State
  law, the City unconstitutionally â€œcriminalized conduct that is not illegal
  under State criminal laws governing the same subject.â€Â  Because we find the
  Ordinance does not criminalize conduct, we hold it does not run afoul of
Article VIII, section 14 of the Constitution.
Although Article VIII deals generally with the creation of local government, Article VIII, section
  14 limits certain powers of local governments. Â See City of North Charleston v. Harper, 306 S.C. 153, 155-56, 410 S.E.2d 569, 570 (1991).
  Â Section 14 provides, in pertinent part:Â  â€œIn
  enacting provisions required or authorized by this article, general law
  provisions applicable to the following matters shall not be set aside: Â â€¦(5)
  criminal laws and the penalties and sanctions for the transgression thereof.â€Â  S.C.
Const., art. VIII, Â§ 14. Â 
We have observed that this subsection of the
  Constitution requires â€œstatewide uniformityâ€ regarding the criminal law of this
  State, and therefore, â€œlocal governments may not criminalize conduct
  that is legal under a statewide criminal law.â€Â  Martin v. Condon, 324
  S.C. 183, 478 S.E.2d 272, 274 (1996) (emphasis added); accord Connor
    v. Town of Hilton Head Island, 314 S.C. 251, 442 S.E.2d 608 (1994) (where
  the Court held that a municipality cannot criminalize nude dancing when State
law does not).  
While the Ordinance in this case does make smoking in
  certain areas â€œunlawfulâ€ where the Clean Indoor Air Act does not, it is our opinion
  the Ordinance does not criminalize such behavior.Â  Instead, the Ordinance
  states that a violation constitutes â€œan infraction.â€Â  â€œInfractionâ€ is defined
as:  

	A breach, violation, or infringement; as of a law, a
  contract, a right or a duty.Â  A violation of a statute for which the only
  sentence authorized is a fine and which violation is expressly designated as an
infraction.

Blackâ€™s
Law Dictionary 537 (6th ed. 1992). Â 
Put simply, the plain language of the Ordinance is
  non-criminal in nature.Â  This contrasts
  with the Clean Indoor Air Actâ€™s â€œmisdemeanorâ€ language which clearly indicates that
a violation of the State law is considered a criminal offense.
Citing Connor v. Town of Hilton Head Island, supra, respondents argue this Court has held that a local ordinance
  cannot make an activity illegal when it is otherwise legal under State law.Â 
  They contend that based on this holding, the Ordinance must be struck down.Â  In Connor, we stated that Article VIII, section 14 â€œprohibit[s] a
  municipality from proscribing conduct that is not unlawful under State criminal
  laws governing the same subject.â€Â  314 S.C. at 254, 442 S.E.2d at 609.Â  It was
  clear, however, that the local ordinance at issue in Connor, which
  prohibited nude or semi-nude dancing, criminalized such conduct.Â  In support of
  our holding, we stated as follows:Â  â€œSince Town has criminalized conduct
  that is not unlawful under relevant State law, we conclude Town exceeded its
  power in enacting the ordinance in question.â€Â  Id. at 254, 442 S.E.2d at
610.Â   
In the instant case, however, where the violation of
  the Ordinance constitutes an infraction or a public nuisance, the conclusion is
  inescapable that the City does not seek to criminalize any conduct.Â  As such,
  the Ordinance does not â€œset asideâ€ the criminal laws of this State.Â  Accordingly,
  we find trial court erred in finding that the Ordinance violates Article VIII,
section 14 of the South Carolina Constitution.
Finally, we hold the Ordinance is consistent with the
Constitution and the general law of the State.
South Carolina law
provides that each municipality of this State may enact:

	regulations, resolutions, and ordinances, not
  inconsistent with the Constitution and general law of this State, including the
  exercise of powers in relation to roads, streets, markets, law enforcement,
  health, and order in the municipality or respecting any subject which appears
  to it necessary and proper for the security, general welfare, and convenience
  of the municipality or for preserving health, peace, order, and good government
in it.â€

S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 5-7-30 (2004).Â  Under the State Constitution, â€œall laws concerning
  local government shall be liberally construed in their favor.â€Â  S.C. Const. art.
  VIII, Â§ 17.Â  â€œA municipal ordinance is a legislative enactment and is presumed
  to be constitutional.â€Â  Sunset Cay, LLC v. City of Folly Beach, 357 S.C. 414, 425, 593 S.E.2d 462, 467 (2004).Â  Furthermore, â€œ[a]s a
  general rule, â€˜additional regulation to that of State law does not constitute a
  conflict therewith.â€™â€Â  Denene, 352 S.C. at 214, 574 S.E.2d at 199
(citation omitted).
The City claims that the Ordinance is a proper
  exercise of municipal power because it seeks to protect citizens from
  second-hand smoke.Â  See Â§ 5-7-30 (municipality may enact ordinance which
promotes general welfare and preserves health).Â  We agree.
In Denene, this Court found that a local
  ordinance which prohibited commercial establishments
  that allow alcohol consumption from operating between the hours of 2 a.m. and 6
  a.m. on Mondays through Saturdays did not conflict with State law which
  prohibited the sale of alcohol between twelve
  oâ€™clock Saturday night and sunrise Monday morning.Â  The Denene Court held that because the local ordinance was â€œneither inconsistent nor
  irreconcilableâ€ with the State statute, it was a proper and valid exercise of
the cityâ€™s police power.Â  Denene, 352 S.C. at 215, 574 S.E.2d at 199.
The situation in the instant case is akin to that in Denene.Â 
  While the State has legislated restrictions on smoking in certain areas, a
  civil ordinance which adds areas does not in any way conflict with the State
  law.Â  â€œMere differences in detail do not render [statutes] conflicting.Â  If
  either is silent where the other speaks, there can be no conflict between
  them.Â  Where no conflict exists, both laws stand.â€Â  Town of Hilton Head
    Island v. Fine Liquors, Ltd., 302 S.C. at 553, 397 S.E.2d at 664 (internal
quotes and citation omitted).
Thus, it is our opinion that the Ordinance is
consistent with the Constitution and the general law of the State.
CONCLUSION
For the reasons discussed above, we hold the Ordinance
  passed by the City is valid and enforceable.Â  Therefore, we reverse the trial
courtâ€™s order.  
REVERSED.

TOAL, C.J., MOORE, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


[1] Some exceptions are allowed under the Clean Indoor Air Act such as designated smoking
  areas in employee break areas and private offices. See Â§ 44-95-20.Â 
  Furthermore, the statute expressly permits certain expansions in the delineated
  categories; for example, the statute does not prohibit:Â  (1) school districts
  from providing for a smoke-free campus; or (2) health care facilities from
being smoke-free. Â Id.Â   
[2] According to the title of
  Act 445, the amendment to the Clean Indoor Air Act was â€œto revise the areas in
  which a person may smoke in public schools and provide that local school boards
may make school district facilities smoke free.â€
[3] We are aware that several opinions of the Attorney
  General have come to a different conclusion, and respondents urge us to adopt the
  Attorney Generalâ€™s view of this issue.Â  See Op. S.C. Attâ€™y Gen., 2007 WL
  1651346 (May 1, 2007); Op. S.C. Attâ€™y Gen., 2006 WL 269614 (Jan. 26, 2006);
  1990 Op. S.C. Attâ€™y Gen. 196 (1990).Â  The 1990 opinion reviewed whether the
  Clean Indoor Air Act preempted localities from further regulating smoking and
  found that â€œlocal political subdivisions would be prohibited, at least
    implicitly, from further regulation of smoking in public indoor places.â€Â  (emphasis
  added).Â  Under this Courtâ€™s law, however, preemption must be explicit, not
  implicit. Â Bugsyâ€™s, supra.Â  Furthermore, we note this
Court is not bound by opinions of the Attorney General.Â  Eargle v. Horry County, 344 S.C. 449, 455, 545 S.E.2d 276, 280 (2001).
